subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
That this House condemns the government for its failure to be completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
March 24. 1992

Supply
He said: Mr. Speaker, the motion before us today condemns the government for its failure to be completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
All those who have followed the debates in the House of Commons in recent weeks and months will be fully aware of the absence of adequate information for the Canadian people about the goals and objectives of this government in the current North American free trade discussions. That situation has arisen despite the fact that the all-party committee of this House has called repeatedly on the government and in the strongest terms to make available information about its purposes in being a participant in the North American free trade negotiations.
The motion before us today must be seen against the background of course of the U.S.-Canada free trade agreement. It is not often in life that one gets a second chance. Fortunately, Canada has been provided with an opportunity to correct some of the shortcomings and inadequacies that are clearly embodied in the free trade agreement during the current Canada-Mexico-United States negotiations.
Only the most sanguine among us would argue that the existing United States-Canada free trade agreement has lived up to its promises, certainly the extravagant promises made by the government in 1988. The government's central justification at that time and subsequently was that secure access had been won in the U.S. market despite the increasing United States protectionism. Since then, however, there has been a whole series of more specific trade disputes, from Honda automobiles to softwood lumber. All of those and others have demonstrated just how tenuous and arbitrary that access to the U.S. market remains. Indeed, those trade disputes have underscored what we in the opposition have claimed all along, namely that the eleventh-hour agreement negotiated by the government was essentially unfinished and seriously flawed.
The shaky dispute settlement mechanism that was embodied in that eleventh-hour agreement was no substitute for a binding agreement between the two countries in such areas as subsidies, countervail and content requirements. Unless a clear definition of the rules of trade were to be established, Canada could not
hope to enjoy what it sought in the talks, that is a truly level playing field with the United States.
Likewise, only the most obtuse would argue that this argument has adequately prepared Canada for the free trade agreement, not merely the Mexico-Canada-United States agreement but the U.S.-Canada free trade agreement.
Despite the explicit recommendations of the Macdonald royal commission, among many other studies, virtually no attempt was made by this government to link trade liberalization to a comprehensive program of domestic reform. There is no adjustment assistance programs of the required nature for business or for labour, let alone real social reform.
Those were the initiatives which would have enabled Canadians to help manage the transitions and dislocations which inevitably accompany greater trade liberalization.
Equally, little headway was made by the government in the removal of interprovincial trade barriers, barriers which to this day hinder Canadians from realizing their full potential in export trade. They hinder Canadians in realizing the potential of larger and more effective corporations and more effective employment of our labour force to ensure our entry into not only the United States market but global markets which are becoming so evident a feature of the international landscape.
The government continued to pursue a conflicting domestic agenda. An expansionary fiscal policy was combined, quite perversely in my view, with a tight monetary policy. That is to say Canadian industry was gradually handicapped with high interest rates and an over-valued dollar at the very time that Canadian exports were trying to penetrate the U.S. market. The two policies, fiscal and monetary, were in direct contradiction. On the one hand, the government sought freer trade with the United States, and at the same time pursued a monetary policy which not only resulted in higher interest rates but so drove up the Canadian dollar as to render a good number of Canadian exports to the United States and elsewhere non-competitive.
After the experience of the last three years, one would have thought that by now the government might have learned from its past mistakes. Given the fact that the existing free trade agreement was badly fumbled, one would have thought that the government might have

March 24, 1992
Supply
approached this new round of negotiations with a strategic game plan; one which at a minimum would have set out Canada's national objectives; one which would have outlined how Canada will challenge and exploit a North American free trade agreement; one which would have laid down a concurrent program of domestic adjustment to help Canadian businesses and Canadian workers to compete effectively in the markets to the south and, indeed, on a global basis.
Finally, one might have expected this government to explain to the Canadian people how North American free trade fits into a wider global trade strategy for Canada.
In short, in all these and in other areas Canada is in real need of a collective response to the end of the post war era and the emergence of economic globalization. Unfortunately, no such plan has been brought forward by this government in response to the circumstances of the U.S.-Canada free trade agreement or of the proposed North American free trade agreement.
The best that Canadians have been offered by this government are bald platitudes about how free trade with Mexico naturally will lead to more jobs in Canada, better opportunities for Canadians and greater investment in Canadian industry. This is the same kind of thinking which assumed that a policy of tearing down the walls and rolling back the state will, unaided, ensure growth and prosperity. This abiding faith in the market's invisible hand has not proved sufficient over the past three years and there is certainly no reason to think that it will prove any more adequate today as we face a North American free trade agreement.
For this reason four central points must be addressed by this government:
First, we need a clear and open statement from the government about its specific objectives in the current negotiations. For example, will a subsidies code be part of the trilateral agreement; will the dispute settlement mechanism be comprehensive and binding; will this agreement include an accession clause to open the door to other potential partners in the western hemisphere; and finally, is this government prepared to hold the line against U.S. demands in such areas as culture, telecommunications and investment?
All these questions are being left unanswered. They are pressing and increasingly pressing, but the government makes no effort to explore and develop them with the people of Canada.
Second, we need to develop a national plan for exploiting the opportunities presented by global freer trade. Many sectors of the Canadian economy exhibit the adverse effects of having evolved behind protectionist walls. Those factors that are common to such industries include a reluctance to innovate and upgrade; a failure to reach and expand beyond a domestic market; an increasingly narrow product range, especially in the export sector; and an aversion to foreign and domestic rivalry.
All this suggests that we in Canada need to change our mind-set about global economic integration. At a minimum, we need a domestic economic environment more conducive to export-led growth. We need to identify those sectors where Canada does, or should, enjoy a competitive advantage and focus our collective energies in these areas. We need to encourage Canadian business to form trade consortia, joint ventures, to gain an early foothold in foreign markets including, for example, the Mexican market. Finally, we need to educate Canadian business about foreign markets including, in this case, Mexico, its economic climate, its culture and, of course, its language, by building linkages among our educational institutions and the private sector.
Third, we must respond to the whole adjustment challenge. Canada remains, unfortunately, without a comprehensive adjustment assistance program for business and labour. Although this was a cornerstone of the government's 1988 free trade package, it was a cornerstone that it failed completely to put in place. The government, for its part, argues that there are already adjustment assistance programs in place, well over 200, it tells us, dispersed among the various provincial and federal jurisdictions. Yet, the very existence of these unconnected ad hoc programs is an argument for consolidating the system and making it more successful.
More to the point, current unemployment figures, over 1.4 million Canadians out of work or 10.2 per cent of the work force, attest to the failure of these programs to help Canadians to adjust. There can be little doubt that our labour intensive sector, such as textiles, will be
March 24, 1992

seriously exposed by a North American free trade agreement.
By the same token, there is every indication that our advanced industries could suffer from labour and capital shortages in the very near future. Are we going to wait until the market's so-called invisible hand works its magic or is there something that the government can do to help the economy respond to market signals? The answer, of course, is a massive and determined program of adjustment assistance which this government has singularly and completely failed to provide.
Fourth, we need to develop a global trade strategy without or with the North American free trade agreement. Canada's growing links with Mexico are part and parcel of our growing links with the world economy as a whole. Yet, the present government has done little to address these fundamental trends. A much vaunted Pacific Rim initiative has yet to progress beyond the rhetorical stage. There has been virtually no attempt, public or private, to exploit the major opportunities presented in the European Community in 1992, nor has the government seized the opportunity of the opening up of eastern Europe as a possible trade option for Canada and, more important, as a back door into the European Community.
As far as Latin America is concerned, the government has failed to formulate, let alone implement, a trade strategy except in reaction to the recent United States and Mexican initiatives, not its own trade initiatives, but initiatives forced on it by the United States and Mexico.
This passive approach to globalization raises serious questions about the direction of Canada's trade policy. It is for that reason that we sought in the motion today more information, open and candid discussion with Canadians about the government's goals and objectives in its trade policy.
For example, a strictly continentalist free trade arrangement will, by definition, make Canadian industry even more focused on the United States market and overly susceptible to the fluctuations of the U.S. economy, such as the current United States recession.
Supply
Canada's growing trade deficits, the imbalances that we really must correct are with our partners overseas, especially with Asia, not with the United States with which we continue to enjoy a surplus.
The deteriorating competitive position of the U.S. economy, together with a growing ascendancy of Europe and the Pacific Rim, raise serious doubts as to whether North America is still the benchmark against which Canadian industry must measure itself.
Developments in technology and transport are effectively diminishing geographical barriers, especially for the high value added industries of the future such as telecommunications and financial services. This should allow Canada to be part of a global and not merely a continental economy.
Finally, rising protectionist sentiments in the United States together with indications that its first priority is enhanced trade links with the hemisphere-the current Mexico-Canada-U.S. trade negotiations is merely the first step-raises the question of whether Canada is drifting into a U.S. dominated trade bloc and perhaps a new continentalist form of protection, and thus away from the global economy.
These are all serious issues which the government has yet to address. In its failure to offer Canadians a full account of why it is Canada is participating in the North American free trade agreement and what it is that we seek in those negotiations, the government is merely underlining its bankruptcy of policy to cope with the fact that a global trading and investment world has arrived.
We see a reflection of this in the government's current and expensive policy of sending a group of people across the country to consult on its so-called prosperity initiative.
All Canadians know what has to be done. There is no need for another year of consultation with Canadian people to know that adjustment assistance has been a principal failure of this government. It has rolled back the trade barriers in North America with the U.S.-Cana-da Free Trade Agreement. It now contemplates doing so with regard to Mexico as well and possibly with some

March 24, 1992
Supply
other western hemisphere countries, but it offers no reassurance to the Canadian people, Canadian workers or Canadian business that the necessary changes Canada must undertake as it moves from a resource dominated economy to a value added economy are in place to make that transition and to make it in a way that will assure jobs and affluence for the Canadian people.
The failure of this government has been in its lack of candour and open discussion with the Canadian people about what it is that it seeks in the trade negotiations and in its failure to help Canadians adjust to the challenges presented not only by the two free trade agreements under discussion today but in the current Uruguay round of the GATT that effectively presents many of the same challenges with which these two trade agreements confront Canadians.
There is an essential role for the government to play. There is an active role for the government to play, and it is past time that this government came forward with a comprehensive program to assist Canadians to take full advantage of the globalization of trade and investment which is taking place across the world today.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with great interest to my colleague berating the present free trade agreement and the proposed North American free trade agreement.
I am quite sure he will agree that the free trade agreement we entered into gave us some special privileges over and above our many other trading countries. He is also aware, I think it was three or four years ago, that the American trade deficit was as high as $175 billion. Again, if my memory serves me right, I believe there were between 300 and 400 pieces of legislation in the United States Congress either to prohibit imports, to limit them, or to put a higher tariff on them or a quota.
It certainly has not turned out as well as Canada wanted, but we are in a much more preferential position than a great many of our trading partners and other trading countries. If the existing one is so bad, why are these countries clamouring, and one might say drooling at the mouth, to try to get the same deal?
My colleague can also rest assured that our government, in working out a deal for the North American free agreement, is certainly not going to give anything away.
It is going to be a deal that is acceptable to us and advantageous to us.
I would appreciate the member's comments with respect to the free trade agreement and what the Americans would have done if we had not had that. At the present time we have a special disputes tribunal which gives us an opportunity. I think he will agree that if we did not have that any decision by the United States department of commerce, or whatever it is, would just be a fait accompli and we could do nothing about it.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am glad to have the government member's assurance that in the Mexico-Ca-nada-U.S. talks nothing the government will do will jeopardize Canadian interests.
The point I want to make is that in seeking a reassurance of Canadian interests in such a discussion it is also incumbent upon the government to match the removal or reduction in trade barriers with a dynamic and comprehensive program of assistance at home.
This government in its commitment to withdraw from the markets, as it would itself term it, has not provided that assistance to Canadians.
On the member's second point with regard to secure access, I would ask him whether he is saying in effect that the bottle is half full or half empty. I cannot think that in the light of the prolonged discussion of the pork issue, and more recently the problems that have arisen over softwood lumber and Honda automobiles or Japanese built automobiles in Canada, he can think that we have in effect secured that access which we were promised we would have within the free trade agreement.
I would suggest to him that the evidence in the case for example of the Honda autos is one where the United States has concluded that by harassing-and I believe that I use the Prime Minister's word-a Japanese company making automobiles in Canada it hopes to ensure that future Japanese or other foreign investment is directed into the United States itself rather than into Canada, or possibly in the North American free trade agreement into Mexico, by demonstrating that if an investment is made in either of those other two countries or particularly in Canada, the harassment will lead the foreign investor to conclude that he might as well have invested directly in the United States in the first instance.

I would suggest that is not an effective and secure access system to the U.S. market. The dispute settlement mechanism is prolonged. It is clumsy. It does not provide in the end for binding decisions unless the two parties have reached prior agreement that the decision will be binding. It does not deal effectively with U. S. countervail as it is called in the business. The effectiveness of how to contain the problems of U.S. reaction to Canadian trade initiatives has not been resolved by this agreement. It is for such reasons that we on this side of the House have called for further discussions with the United States to ensure that those aspects of the agreement which are flawed be identified and resolved.

Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure to join in the debate on behalf of the government and perhaps to put a few of the issues inherent in this motion in their proper context, but not to intervene and mediate the obvious lovers' quarrel between the two opposition parties.
The member for Etobicoke North makes two points really. One is that there is not enough information about the government's objectives that we have taken to these over-all North American free trade talks. The second is that we have not put in place sufficient adjustment

March 24, 1992
Supply
measures to prepare our own economy and our own people for the impact of a general North American free trade agreement and the impact of changes that are occurring throughout the world.
I will dispel the myth about not enough information, not enough consultation. I will leave it to my other colleagues for the rest of the day to dispel the myth about a lack of preparation and adjustment measures.
My hon. friend is quite right when he says that the magic of old, the invisible hand of Adam Smith and many of the things that we relied upon in the past to regulate the economies of our own countries, of our own jurisdictions and those of the world, that these old rules no longer work. The magic no longer works. Indeed, the economies are very much influenced today by very powerful global forces, forces over which not one single nation, one single powerful jurisdiction as there may be, has any control.
I would like to put in context the background against which we have made some of these decisions, first of all, to enter into a free trade arrangement with the United States and then to quickly respond when we discovered that the Americans were looking to expand these kinds of arrangements south to Mexico to make sure that our own interests would not be adversely affected.
We live in a new age. It is called the technology age or the information age. There are megatrends that sweep around the planet in microseconds, trends that no one has any ability to steer or to influence to any extent. That is the first context. No one will be able to hide, protect or shelter themselves from these forces of which I spoke.
The population of the planet has doubled in the last 150 years. It will double again in the next 75 years. Anyone who is under any illusion that this trend will not have a very profound and very serious impact on the way we do business with one another, the way we rearrange our own lifestyles, our own quality of life, is very naive.
Since our travels to space we have a keener awareness of the fragility of the planet, of the finite resources that we are using. These resources will have to be shared, not with 4.5 billion but perhaps with 7 billion to 9 billion people in just 75 years from now.
Perhaps it is also because of the fact that peace has broken out. There is no longer a major confrontation between the superpowers. This requires major adjustments in the economies of some of the more powerful countries, particularly the United States and the Soviet Union, an economy which was in the main based on defence production.
All of those things will have a very profound impact on the way we do business. It is an impact, as I said, that will come down on us, which will affect us whether or not we stick our heads in the sand. These are trends that have to be responded to, that have to be faced and managed.
As I said earlier, not even the most powerful among us of the nation states has any capacity to control these trends. Capital moves throughout the world without restrictions in seconds.
Investment decisions are made by corporations that are more powerful today in their global context than most nation states in the world. Investment decisions are being made on the grounds of perhaps less stringent environmental and human rights standards in one part of the world as compared to another.
So there is a call for a new world order. It would have been heresy 10 years ago for a president of the most powerful nation on earth, the United States, to admit and to show readiness to surrender much of the sovereignty of the United States to a new world order.
Why is that? The reason is because of the facts that I have mentioned. Not even that most powerful nation on earth has any control over these new developments. No one will be sheltered, no one will be excused from making the tough decisions that have been made in our country to prepare ourselves for these new events.
Perhaps the changes are so profound that even the political institutions, including our own, may well not be suited to cope with these new developments. We have to prepare ourselves for this concept of a new world order, this concept of globalization.
One of the unfortunate features in our system, and it is not just in the British parliamentary system but most traditional political systems of a free market economy, is what the opposition parties see as their role to stop progress. I am not being critical here. It is an inherent
March 24, 1992

part of our political system. They see it as their role to stop progress at any cost. That is one part of their role. The other part of their role is to lament the fact that there is no progress. That is part of our system and we have to live with that. But I hope the people who look in on some of these debates are fully aware of that.
In developing our own policy and our own strategy, obviously we were inclined to look at the European experience. As we looked around the world we discovered that anywhere free trade has happened things happen quickly and all the developments, in the main, are positive.
In Europe there is the European Economic Community, a consortium or strategic alliance of nations. They fought and killed each other for thousands of years for all kinds of reasons and all of a sudden they have come together to talk about free trade, economic and industrial integration, about a single standard throughout Europe. They go further. They talk about political integration. They are talking about surrendering part of their sovereignty to a larger order, in this case the European Economic Community.
Why would they do this? Well, perhaps they are better students of history and they have a longer history than we have here in our own country. They can think back to the dark ages. Incidentally, countries in eastern Europe tend to relive the Dark Ages by pursuing selfish, parochial interests. Europeans have overcome that and there are good reasons for it. They know that only through that kind of combined strength and by putting aside our parochial interests can we cope with these new trends that are at the same time a bit frightening and daunting. It is human to resist change, particularly such profound changes but of course they are also very, very exciting.
Europeans also know that unless they get their act together, unless they break down the barriers and unless freedom breaks out in eastern Europe there could be an influx of 30 million refugees into the central European space. All of that has to be considered.

They have a social charter, but my hon. friend of course thinks that all the ills would be solved by just writing out a social charter and the very next day everybody would be happy, just like everybody was happy the very next day after we had a human rights charter in the last Constitution. It is not that simple.
These predictions of doom and gloom are just simple nonsense.
We cannot ignore the dangers on the one hand, as I said, and the opportunities on the other that present themselves as we enter into these discussions, and that would have presented themselves if we had not entered into these discussions.
Let us put the North American market in its context. There are 360 million people, the most powerful trading block on earth, with a gross domestic product or an economy that exceeds $6 trillion. Mexico has 85 million to 90 million people who will be added to this trading block. Mexico will be the spring-board to extend our trading arrangements beyond our hemisphere to the south.
Our objectives were clearly spelled out by one of Canada's chief negotiators in a speech on June 3, 1981. He clearly spelled out what the objectives are that he has been told to pursue at the talks. He and his colleagues made 26 major speeches in the country. These are all public documents. Our major objective is the elimination of tariffs, of course. That is the basis of any free trade
agreement that is negotiated between any two partners, protecting intellectual property rights, dispute mechanisms, rules of origin, better definitions of rules relating to subsidies, all of these kinds of things, some of which perhaps, as we know today, are a bit weak in the Canada-U.S. arrangement and there is the potential now for us to strengthen those.
Immediately after the launch of the talks on June 12 of last year, situation reports had been issued and published to all stakeholders. Three thousand of these reports have been published. So what is the opposition talking about? As I said, the SAGITs have been reorganized. A broad spectrum of interests have been involved in the negotiations: business, academics, labour, environmental groups.
If the hon. members opposite were really interested in these objectives, they had only to attend the briefings that were organized by the subcommittee on external affairs and international trade. Read any of the many speeches I have mentioned by the minister and the chief negotiator or spend a few minutes pursuing one of the three situation reports that have been published and tabled.
Had they taken any of these initiatives, they would have learned that Canada has five broad objectives in the NAFTA negotiations. I will spell them out just so there can no longer be any doubt. First, barrier free access to Mexico for Canadian goods and services while developing tariff phase out provisions and safeguard mechanisms which reflect Canadian import sensitivities. Second, improved access to the United States markets in such areas as financial services and government procurement. Third, improved conditions under which Canadian business can make strategic alliances with North America to better compete with the Pacific rim and the European Community as well as other parts of the world not so critical. In unity, there is strength and by getting ourselves competitive in our own hemisphere and our own environment here, we will be stronger to approach the markets of the rest of the world, which are so terribly exciting and ensure that Canada remains an attractive site for foreign and domestic investment. That, too, is important. Finally, the establishment and expeditious dispute settlement mechanism.

The record of the government is unequivocal. We consulted with Canadians before we decided to enter the NAFTA negotiations. We have consulted continuously since the negotiations were launched last June. We are continuing to consult on an ongoing basis with the provinces, with the representatives of business and labour, with academics, with environmental interests and with the many Canadians who wish to air their views and have input into these discussions.
We have consulted with our colleagues in the committee to which they have access and in which they really set the agenda.
The objectives of Canada's negotiators have been known for almost a year. The broad consultative process solicits a two-way flow of information.
In short, the motion placed before this House by the opposition does not accurately reflect the facts and it should be withdrawn.
Mr. Speaker, a final word. Instead of condemning the government for having the courage to do some of these things that may perhaps be a bit daunting and frightening, in approaching a path that is still shrouded in the mist of what the future might bring, they should celebrate the fact that we have a government that has a clear fix on the future and is clearly attuned to the horrendous changes and the excitement that is happening throughout the world today.

This is a sell-out and this government is too stupid to understand it. And the Liberals think that by going back on the fence they can win an election.
I say this. Let the election be called on this issue. Let the people of this country decide. Not the smoke and mirrors in this Chamber, but let the people of this country decide who is fighting for the working people, who is fighting for Canadian sovereignty. It is not the government and tragically it is not the Liberals. We are left alone in the struggle but we intend to maintain it.
Mr. Speaker, if you will let me put my amendment, I move:
That the motion be amended by adding the following words:
and therefore call upon the government to withdraw from the negotiations.

Mr. Speaker, I will be sharing my time with the hon. member for York North.
I think it is a very appropriate time to have an opposition day on this topic. I want to commend my colleague from Etobicoke North for the motion he put forward, the motion that this House condemn the government for its failure to be completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
Supply
I listened intently to the member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca and I hope that they will realize now that it is the government that is the target in these negotiations. They are the ones that are doing the negotiating. It is not the Liberal Party and I hope they will not make the same mistake again as was made in 1988 when their leader attacked the Liberal Party because we were ahead in the polls at the time. Of course they were desperately trying to grasp on to straws like a drowning person to maintain their place as one of the opposition parties in the House of Commons.
The negotiations that are being conducted at the present time are similar to the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. This government is not telling Canadians what it is getting them into because the government itself does not know because it has not done its homework prior to these negotiations.
For example, I just want to give you the fact that in the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement it was not until this past month that the Minister of Agriculture finally got a handle on what subsidies and supports are received by United States farmers and food processors. A working paper was published entitled "Assistance Programs for U.S. Agriculture and Food Processors".
It is well known that the U.S. farmers, particularly grain farmers, get about a third to one-half of their income from government subsidies. Yet this government did not pause to look into this. It is only after the fact that it has become known. Now we look at the hardship being inflicted on Canadian farmers and the millions and millions of dollars in subsidies we have had to pay out to them to even remain in business.
The study states the main purpose was to provide information which might be useful in the development of rules for the use of government subsidies as envisaged in the Canada-U.S. trade agreement. Yet this study was published three years after the agreement came into effect. The study was not even commissioned until after the free trade agreement was signed.
Is this how one negotiates with a stronger adversary, by waiting until after the ink on the contract is dry before investigating the strengths and weaknesses of one's adversary?

March 24, 1992
Supply
I would suggest not. I am appalled at what has happened since that trade agreement came into effect. Some 49 food processing plants in Ontario were closed, 83 across Canada, and thousands upon thousands of jobs were lost, jobs that have moved south of the border and now may even move farther south.
It is evident that the government has not been master of its own timetable. Canada has responded to an accelerated agenda largely set by Mexico and the United States. This has contributed to a situation where the government has not only failed to consult the Canadian people and the Official Opposition but has also failed to provide a clear and thorough analysis of the conditions that Canada has placed on its participation, what substantive goals it seeks, and how it proposes to reach those goals.
When this government plays to the corporate agenda it makes a mockery out of this parliamentary system and of the democratic process itself.
There are several areas that I am deeply concerned about as associate critic for trade and associate critic for agriculture. Our premise is that the free trade agreement really ignores the reality of the agricultural geography of North America. Our contention is that with respect to agriculture the free trade agreement is fatally flawed. The reality of Canadian and U.S. agriculture is such that a level playing field is an impossibility. Mother nature dictates that. Furthermore, it is an attempt to impose a model solution that will ultimately undermine the vitality of our industry in Canada.
There are three basic contradictions in the assumptions of the free trade agreement. The first contradiction applies to a more open and secure export market. Canadian agriculture is based on an inherently inferior physical base which plays the major role in reducing over-all productivity by as much as 50 per cent compared to the U.S.
The second is in respect to the protection of domestic production under supply management. While it is true these arrangements are presently sanctioned under article XI(c) of the GATT, they are clearly trade distorting in the bilateral context of the free trade agreement. It is the free trade agreement that is putting pressure on the GATT. If in fact article XI(2)(c) is not maintained, enhanced and clearly spelled out, this will lead to the demise of the poultry and dairy sector in Canada.
Considered together these lead to the conclusion that the free trade agreement will amplify the inherent distinction between the two systems and tend to erode the evolved ones such that Canadian agriculture may not only be less discrete but may decline to become merely the extensive margins of a North American system.
In Canada, 2 per cent of our crop land falls in the highest thermal category versus 81 per cent in the United States. Some 24 per cent of our crop land falls into the adequate moisture category versus 57 per cent in the United States. I submit this translates into a startling situation whereby the United States alone has 130 times the crop land in optimal agroclimatic conditions than Canada has.
Now the government adds a new dimension that allows for us to compete against a nation that does not have the same standard as we do. DDT is still used in Mexico. It has been banned in Canada for many years. There are many other chemicals, pesticides and herbicides we are not allowed to use here in Canada. When they are banned in Canada it means that we have a zero tolerance level. Is it the same for our imported foods? I suggest not. Our regulations indicate that we have minimum levels of standards that allow products into this country produced under conditions entirely different from what we have in Canada.
We had to read about this agreement in The Toronto Star this morning. I had a sneak preview last week in a small newspaper out of Michigan headlined "The opposition to Mexican free trade grows". It spells it out very clearly. Of course The Toronto Star this morning told Canadian people exactly what was happening. It is very evident when I mention the number of food processing plants that closed in Canada.
I want to just go on a little further. The relocation of U.S. food processors in Mexico always disrupts the lives of American workers. Many Americans who have worked in the food industry have lost their jobs and have received no compensation or retraining.
I want to quote a statement by the president of the National Farmers Union, Mr. Easter. He said:
Consumer prices, however, will remain at constant high levels even though the quality of food will erode as more chemicals are used. The corporations are going to Mexico because they can make higher profits there.
March 24, 1992

I am appalled at the lack of environmental safeguards in the agreement. It makes a mockery out of the green plan. Why do negotiators not demand that both the United States and Mexico measure up to our standards in terms of automotive emissions, the use of pesticides, herbicides and chemicals that I referred to a moment ago?
Today the Government of Canada has no loyalty to the Canadian people; only to the transnational corporate interests. Rather than leading by example and purchasing Canadian products, we were appalled just recently about the purchase of Canadian needs in the U.S., particularly the order for U.S. built locomotives for a Crown corporation in Canada, Canadian National.
I am also appalled that the purchase of carpet for one of the buildings of this institution was made through a U.S. firm.
When the government talks about Canadian standards and talks about the advantages of buying Canadian, I suggest that it should lead the way. It should show the example. It should maintain our standards here in Canada. If we are going to have free trade with Mexico, let it come up to our standards. Let it bring its wages up to our standards and let it bring its standard of living up to what we have here in Canada for the benefit of all of North America.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question because I indicated in my address that 83 food processing plants have closed in Canada since January 1989 when free trade came in.
In Ontario where a lot of the soft fruit is grown, as well as in British Columbia, 49 food processing plants have closed and 5,635 jobs were lost. Many of these are gone forever. When this government came into power one of the first things it did was to go through a process it called standardization of regulations. In some cases it meant that the regulations we had in Canada in the food sector, which were among the most stringent in the world, were watered down to compare to that of our neighbours to the south.
I mentioned the fact that many of the pesticides, herbicides and chemicals currently used in other countries are not allowed in Canada. This will have a dramatic impact on our whole system as grade standards and so on are brought down.
I noticed that even the labour rates in the U.S. that are being paid to workers in the orchards and the fruit and vegetables business are very low compared to those in Canada. The writing is on the wall unless we as Canadians step in and insist that our industry be protected and our standards be upheld.
In Mexico the minimum wage rate has dropped by almost 60 cents an hour in the last 10 years. The minimum wage rate is now 59 cents per hour. In the Maquiladora area the rate dropped from $1.36 in 1980 to 99 cents an hour in 1989. In the manufacturing sector there was another massive drop. Those rates are going the wrong way. If we were bringing those workers up to Canadian standards we would not have any fear. But for Canada to enter into an agreement such as we have, an agreement that will undermine the viability of our industry in Canada, I believe it is time that we as Canadians made sure that food production and food processing be made a national security item in Canada.
In 1935 the U.S. Food Security Act was brought in for this very purpose. It was was to protect American workers and their food production sector. We need the same thing in Canada. I think it is high time we got on with it.

March 24, 1992

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise for my allotted 10 minutes to speak to the motion put by my colleague and neighbour, the member of Parliament for Etobicoke North. I commend him for suggesting:
That this House condemn the government for its failure to be
completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and
objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
I commend the member for Etobicoke North because the debate this morning on the floor of the House of Commons to be viewed by Canadians on all three coasts could not have been better timed. As this debate has already pointed out, we had to rely this morning on The Toronto Star, as have Canadians, to try to learn what the Government of Canada has been dealing with in terms of the other two countries, namely the United States and Mexico, with respect to a North American free trade agreement.
With all due respect, it is a shame that we have to rely on one of our newspapers to begin to enlighten not only Canadians but elected Canadians who are supposed to deal with issues on behalf of the 26 million shareholders of this company called Canada.
The question ought to be: Why is the House of Commons not seized of the issue? Why is the House of Commons not debating the parameters of what it is that Canada should be pushing for or what Canada should not be encouraging? Why is the House of Commons on behalf of Canadians from coast to coast to coast not giving the green light or the red light to this government? What is democracy all about if we talk about it, preach it and the Prime Minister exports it to the Third World countries? He makes great speeches abroad about the ability of people to exercise their democratic franchise. Yet back home, on an issue that is fundamental to
the livelihoods of all Canadians, there is silence and ignorance. When there is silence and ignorance, whether it is true or not, there is certain to be fear of the unknown at the very least.
What is the reality today with the existing free trade agreement? There is fear and consternation because we are seeing job losses every day. We are experiencing plant closures. We are witnessing movement of goods, capital and factories southward from our border. We are also witnessing no transition programs.
Do you remember the Prime Minister during that 1988 campaign, which was largely a single issue campaign, saying: "At the very worst, Canadians, there will be people displaced by this free trade agreement. There are bound to be transitional difficulties". But for those difficulties he said: "This government will have the best transitional programs in the western world". Ask a 55 year old worker in your riding or mine who has been put on the unemployment or welfare line because the free trade agreement has dramatically altered his lifestyle by closing a factory. Where are those transition programs for that 50 year old worker?
Those programs are called unemployment insurance. After you have exhausted unemployment insurance it is called welfare. After welfare it is good luck. Those are the transition programs this government has put in place since the free trade agreement.
Canadians are asking themselves where the rewards of the free trade agreement are. Where are the rewards this Prime Minister supported, by third person advertisements in the name of these great multinational corporations? The Business Council on National Issues sent letters to employees saying that if they did not get behind the free trade agreement, their jobs would be in peril. Canadians have a right to know where those rewards are today as a result of the free trade agreement. Are there more rewards or more problems as a result of that free trade agreement?
That is the context of the current reality. Add to that Investment Canada, which basically means it is wide open for foreign investment. This party has never been against foreign investment, but the definition of foreign investment to the Tories equates foreign investment with foreign take-overs and we feel that is wrong.
March 24, 1992

Our foreign policy no longer seems to be a Canadian one. It is tied more to the orbit of the United States, as friendly and as good neighbours as they may be. We have airlines looking to the south and perhaps a government decision upping the percentage of foreign investment.
Canadians are not only worried about losing their immediate jobs; the country is aggravated by the free trade agreement. There is fear we are losing the ability to control our own future and our own destiny. The decision-making power seems to be flowing away from us with each and every decision this government makes.
Now we are supposed to blindly give a free ride, a blank cheque to this government to negotiate a North American free trade agreement. Can you imagine? Without any information and with the results clear as day on the free trade agreement, Canadians can only respond with a certain amount of genuine fear for themselves and their nation. The Toronto Star tells us today it is no minor tinkering. The document that was leaked, in terms of the working document Canada is working on, talks about no restrictions on importing goods that were processed in Mexico.
Think about that. If unemployment lines are now stretching, what is it going to mean if Mexicans will be able to export to our country, without any hindrance, when their labour rates are 59 cents an hour?
Government members talk about harmonizing truck, rail and bus transport, but our rail system has been gutted already. Our truckers have been virtually thrown off the road after they have been deregulated because they cannot compete with the Americans. Yet shipping, where we can compete the best, is oddly enough not part of that. The trade agreement only covers areas where we cannot compete.
Telecommunications is going to be opened up. The textile industry is going to be opened up. There may be a complete ban on compulsory licensing, which has permitted generic drug firms in Canada to survive and prosper and keep the cost of prescription drugs at a reasonable rate for Canadians. That will be impossible.
They also talk about a dispute mechanism in the North American free trade context similar to the bilateral one
Supply
which is not working. They expect Canadians to be silent. Are Canadians not supposed to ask this government when it was given the green light to move on these things? What about involving the average citizen, the average Joe, who does give a damn about this country and his or her place in it?
Our party is not as dogmatic as our friends to the left here. This country is a trading country. The Liberal Party has always been a freer trade party. If there has been any history of building walls, it is the party that sits on the government side that has done it. We reserved the right in the last election and we reserve the right again in the next election to say that a deal at any cost is not a deal worth signing. Therefore we bring principles to what should be in or out of a trade agreement. We believe we should be at the table, otherwise who will be protecting and advancing our interests? We believe we should be righting the wrong and using this NAFTA as a way to right the wrong of the FTA.
Canadians must be part of the equation. They cannot be told at the end this is good for them. Canadians must decide for themselves, in conjunction with their Parliament, what is good for themselves, their children and the future of their country.

I would like to thank my hon. friend and colleague for his comment and question.
If the free trade agreement is the benchmark by which this government will conduct itself at the table for NAFTA, we should not only worry about the auto and the agricultural industry, we should worry in general. It should be brought home to him that he does not own this country. This is not his country to play with. This is not his country to experiment with. This is a country he happens to be guiding on a temporary basis, on behalf of Canadians and in their best interests. He
owns nothing. But he owes it to Canadians to deal with the NAFTA deal better than he did the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement. He and the government he leads must learn from their mistakes.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
I am
pleased to be able to take part in this debate today.
I would like to commend the hon. member for Etobicoke North for introducing this motion today and providing the House with the opportunity to have this debate. I have a high regard for the hon. member. I have read many of his articles and have heard him speak. It is too bad his party does not listen to him once in a while.
The debate today is about the question of Canada's trade negotiations with Mexico, but we should also recognize we are involved in trade negotiations with virtually every country in the world, on a bilateral basis as well as through the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs, the current Uruguay round.
These negotiations have enormous implications for all Canadians. It is good to have a day like today where we can express our views and put some comments and facts on the record so Canadians will have an improved knowledge of just what it is the government is trying to do.
I would just like to offer a quote from the C. D. Howe Institute. It said the following with regard to why Canada should participate in these Mexican-United States- Canada trade talks: "By participating, Canada may gain greater opportunities to trade with a newly outwardlooking 85 millions strong market. By standing aloof, Canada risks losing growing Mexican trade to U.S. based companies and losing investment to the United States because only U.S. based firms would have tariff free access to all three markets. If Canada is to be constructively involved in negotiations, it is important that Canada be involved from the beginning".
We are involved from the beginning. We are involved because we want to increase Canada's trade with not only the United States but Mexico and the rest of the world. Canada is the world's second most dependent nation on trade, second only to west Germany.
March 24, 1992

As a trading nation we must be constantly vigilant, looking for new opportunities. We always have to be looking for new opportunities because there is a continuing, if I can use this word, attrition of old opportunities because the world is a changing place.
When we think about trade, opportunities and even lost plants, and we had a lot of discussion this morning about plant closures and how that affects people, the fact of the matter is plant closures do affect people, unfortunately usually in a negative way because at least for a period of time they will be out of a job until there is some other opportunity at some other new plant.
Plant closures have been a fact of life ever since we have had plants, ever since the industrial revolution in the 1700s. The reason we have plant closures is because over time products become obsolete as new and better ones come into the marketplace.
We do not have too much of a buggy whip manufacturing industry these days or an anvil industry or industries that generally support the horse and carriage largely because something new came along called the automobile.
The fact of the matter is those people who were manufacturers of carriages probably had to find new lines of work and new jobs. What we have to recognize as a government and as a country is that the environment needs to be such that new opportunities can be taken advantage of. We allow new plants, new products, new technologies and take the benefit of them rather than trying to hold on to obsolete products and obsolete plants.
The world is better off with these new technologies. These new technologies are often superior goods and services. They also allow fewer people to produce the same volume of goods and services. Who would want to go back to the days of the pick and shovel in constructing roads? I do not think anyone would. That large machinery and equipment that we use in road construction, forestry, mining and all our industries means that we get the same production or more production from a fewer number of people. What that means is that for a time certain people are displaced from their jobs.
If we create the new opportunities, take advantage of the new technologies that are available, we can find new jobs for those people that are both more productive and
Supply
more rewarding at the same time and probably with a greater wage or greater standard of living than we have had in the past. That has been the story of the world for close to 300 years now and there is no real reason to think it should change.
Fighting change, as the NDP would propose through its motion here today, is simply counter-productive.
I would like to speak briefly about some of the opportunities that are available through trade with Mexico if we can negotiate a proper agreement. The president of the World Bank described Mexico's own economic reforms going on there as: "One of the most ambitious, courageous and determined programs of economic reform and institutional change recently undertaken by any country".
In 1988 Northern Telecom's telephone equipment sales to Mexico were worth $4 million. In 1989 sales were $27 million. Sales for 1990 were estimated at over $60 million, and anticipated 1991 for over $100 million and 1992 probably even greater. Mexico has only 6 million telephone lines to serve a population of 85 million. In the next 10 years over $10 billion will be spent on telephone equipment.
Canadians just happen to be the most prolific users of telephones in the world, which probably has something to do with our climate. We therefore have become good at developing telephone systems which we can sell throughout the rest of the world.
A Mexican company has awarded Spar Aerospace a $16 million contract for communications systems used in earth stations and satellite dishes. Air transport equipment sales are expanding rapidly. We have already sold Challenger jet aircraft. Additional sales are anticipated in the future. Mexico City plans to spend about $100 million on public transportation. Canadian companies stand a good chance of participating in this equipment purchase and in getting contracts. Mexico must feed more than 85 million people. Canadian exports of dairy breeding cattle are rising and Canadian farmers anticipate further sales of other dairy and grain products.
All of these are new opportunities. They are opportunities to replace certain plants or certain other economic activities that are becoming obsolete in Canada with new and growing and exciting opportunities.

March 24, 1992
Supply
That is what the government is attempting to do in negotiating this deal. We recognize that over time certain plants and processes become obsolete. New technology to allow us to develop pulp and paper, for example, has allowed northern Alberta to become one of the growth areas in pulp manufacturing in Canada.
Its new technologies have now made it possible to harvest a resource that heretofore had simply been regarded as wasteland. What that does is enable us to bring on this new technology, probably the most pollution efficient plants in the world, or at least in Canada. This means, however, that in order to meet those standards other plants in Canada are going to have to adjust, adapt, and themselves invest in new technology to meet those very strict standards that we are trying to bring into Canada with regard to the environment.
As we know, all Canadians consider the environment to be important. They want those standards, but only through technology can we meet those standards and keep our environment safe.
Some people have said that in Mexico they do not have nearly the same environmental standards and Mexico will become a pollution haven. I would like to address that. First of all, I would like to inform members of the House, in case they are unaware, that the environment is a national priority for Mexico. The government has increased eight-fold its spending on the environment in the last decade and would like to spend more. As we all know, it can only spend more if it has more. It will only have more if it can earn more. One of the ways it can earn more is through increased economic opportunities and trading opportunities.
When we look at Third World countries we all say that we would like them to become self-sufficient on their own or at least be able to become less dependent on foreign aid and be able to bring their standards in regard to pollution and the environment up to something more equivalent to ours. We then turn around and deny them an opportunity by keeping trade barriers on products that they can produce and sell in our markets. Sure we are attempting to protect our own jobs, but at the same time we are denying them opportunities. We are denying them opportunities to increase their incomes which
would then allow them to increase their imports of products that we can provide for them.
It is not productive for us to restrict trade. In fact, it is productive for us to open up trade because with this new income that they have, they will be able to buy more goods and services from us and give us new opportunities for more technologically advanced industries to produce the products and goods and services that they need.
Earlier on the Minister of Forestry spoke. He addressed the question of wages and the fact that some people have said that the wage cost in Mexico is lower than it is in Canada by a substantial amount. That is true, but that is not any reason to try to restrict trade.
Wages generally represent a relatively small part of the total cost of production, on average between 12 per cent and 15 per cent of the cost of production of goods. Less than 2 per cent of the goods Canada buys abroad comes from Mexico in spite of Mexico's lower wages.
Wages are not the only component that goes into the manufacture or product and therefore not the only component that goes into the eventual price. It can be a factor. However, one is presuming when we compare the relatively higher wages in Canada to those in Mexico that those wages are going to stay where they are.
I would suggest that the exact reverse is what will happen and is what we want to happen. We want those people to become involved in the production of goods and services that they can export to the rest of the world. That will allow them to have increased wages for their workers, an increased standard of living, to provide the kinds of money that are necessary to increase their transportation systems, to address economic priorities and social programs which are so badly needed in a country like Mexico and to bring up their environmental standards closer to the industrialized world.
What we are saying is that by allowing them increased opportunities for trade, not only are they going to be able to increase their own economic development, their own standard of living, but through that increased income that they are going to have, they will be able to offer new trading opportunities for Canadians because we still will have the goods and services that they will require.
March 24, 1992

It sounds as though we should try to determine where those opportunities might be and how we can take advantage of them so that we can ensure in Canada that we are not somehow restricting our own companies, our own private sector, from taking full advantage of trade with Mexico or for that matter with the rest of the world.
I think that some of the initiatives that have been taken so far are helpful in that direction. I think the government has been trying to use the private sector through information seminars. I will not list here all the things that go on through documents that are produced by the government outlining potential trade opportunities throughout the world. It organizes trade missions such as we have seen.
Recently, we saw a trade mission, led by the Minister for International Trade, to Japan. It opens up new opportunities and contacts for Canadian businessmen. I think these are the kinds of things through which the government can play a constructive role.
I would think that we would want to see increased trade delegations to Mexico to increase the opportunity for Canadians to go on these trade missions, to develop new contacts with industries in Mexico and to allow trade opportunities to be developed.
One of the problems we have in Canada, being a relatively small country compared to the United States, Japan or Germany and having somewhat smaller businesses if you like, is it is not always completely economic or at least affordable for a smaller company to go on its own trade mission to Japan or to Mexico, to finance itself and to try to find the contacts even though the markets may be there.
One of the things that the government really can do to be helpful to business is to provide these opportunities, to lead the way and to lead delegations that can meet their counterparts or the people in these other countries. After that initial contact, most Canadian businesses are resourceful enough to further develop those contacts and put them into a form of trade, either importing or exporting, that benefits Canadians through the acquisition of new products that we can use.
Supply
They can be economic products, less costly products if you like for consumers but those contacts can allow us to find new markets for our own products that we can sell to produce income and jobs for Canadians.
Trade has been shown over the last 300 years, ever since the industrial revolution, to be something that benefits all economies. Talking about maintaining barriers and restricting trade is simply an attempt to take us back 300 years. Frankly, it seems to me that members of the House here should be addressing how we can develop those opportunities and use Canadian expertise and technology which we know we have.
We know we are capable of producing goods and services that are as good as any other in the world. We can develop and use that to trade with the world, and not look for ways to impinge trade or maintain trade restrictions.
I want to thank the hon. member for Etobicoke North for proposing this motion today and for selecting this topic for debate because it is an important one. It is one that everyone knows during the last election involved considerable discussion. Probably the next one will too. I think it is healthy that the House had this opportunity today. I thank him for that opportunity.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS

Mr. Speaker, first of all, I will say yes, we all have the right to change our minds on the basis of new facts and information. I do that quite often. Frankly, that is the reason we have public hearings, committee hearings and things like that, to get the new information
March 24, 1992

which sometimes turns out to be different from what we thought.
If we were not prepared from time to time to change our minds, there would be no point in holding these hearings and discussions and we would not be serving our own constituents or the Parliament of Canada and the Canadian people very well.
As to the question of whether the free trade agreement has turned out as well as one would hope, the answer is that we know we have had a recession in Canada. We also know that recessions come along from time to time. As far as I know, for the last 500 years we have had recessions. The business cycle is somewhat unpredictable. Therefore, the recession has made it difficult for a number of companies to adjust and in some cases it may have been aggravated by the free trade agreement.
We also knew going into the free trade agreement that there would be substantial changes taking place in the economy, both job losses and job gains. I would say to the hon. member that in my opinion we have had more job gains than job losses. I know that has been true in my province of Alberta. We have had more job gains than job losses.
Yes, I think it has been a good deal on balance and it will be an even better deal once the economy of the United States starts to grow again. They have also been through a recession and once new opportunities for increased exports come about, the free trade agreement will be seen as a great deal and a much improved situation.
I would just like to end by saying one more thing. He said that after the election he determined that some of the things in the fine print were maybe a little different than what he had thought.
It seems to me for somebody who is going to be campaigning it is an admission that he did not bother to read the fine print. Maybe everybody does not have to read the fine print, but people who are campaigning on a substantive issue in a serious way should try and do the best they can to inform themselves of the facts. The fine print was there, it was available and the agreement was all out there.

Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands -
Canso): Mr. Speaker, the motion currently before the House which has been introduced by my colleague the hon. member for Etobicoke North could not be more timely nor could it be more relevant. It comes at a time when Canadians are deeply concerned about a great many matters affecting us all. It comes at a time of uncertainty and uncertainty is the greatest enemy that we face in this country.
By uncertainty, I am speaking of economic and constitutional uncertainty and of the uncertainty Canadians have now with regard to their government and some of their most sacred institutions. Canadians wonder whether those truths, which were once held to be self-evident, are being abandoned in the name of such ill-defined terms as globalism and rationalization.
Canadians are not afraid of change. However, the question that we must grapple with is how best to prepare Canadians for change. Some would argue that this should be the government's top priority and that brings us to the motion that is before the House.
To many Canadians, the North American free trade agreement is a frightening prospect, not because Canadians are afraid of competing with the United States or Mexico or anyone for that matter, but rather because Canadians have seen firsthand what the U.S. free trade agreement has done to our economy and to our national psyche.
Canadians have developed a very deep mistrust of this government. They remember the 1988 election when they were asked to decide on the basis of the then proposed Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement and to choose between two diametrically opposed positions.
In many cases, the debate which followed was conducted with neither honesty nor forthrightness. Rather, it became emotional, in some cases irrational, with accusations and innuendoes being hurled around about people's motivations and their integrity and financed by a third-party campaign which raised serious doubts about the fundamental basis of our democracy.
Since that election, the promises of the government about the successes in our economy which would ensue as a result of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement have not coincided with the experience of Canadians.
Canadians have seen time and time again and have read in their newspapers that Canadian companies are closing down and moving to the United States. Although the government has repeatedly tried to argue that these job losses, these plant closings were not related to the free trade agreement, they were related to something else, it has not assuaged the concerns of Canadians, particularly those who found themselves unemployed with no chance of re-employment.
Canadians have also seen the United States not respect the terms which purportedly they had negotiated in the free trade agreement. We have seen it recently with softwood lumber; we have seen it even more recently with the Honda decision.
Canadians are now once again seeing a familiar pattern emerge with the North American free trade agreement. They see a government that is unwilling to divulge its agenda with regard to its negotiations with the United States and Mexico. When Canadians attempt to learn their government's priorities with respect to these negotiations they are stymied. They are told that these negotiations are too sensitive for public discussion or for public scrutiny.
The result is nagging doubts about whose interests this government truly represents.
Canadians are thus held as captive audiences, forbidden to see what is unfolding on the stage until the principal actors deem it appropriate. Canadians must follow the process as best they can through politically coded messages coming from the Minister of Finance, the Minister for International Trade and the Prime Minister. They are left to wonder and to worry.
Or worse, Canadians find out what is happening through press leaks or through reports coming from agreements being made available to legislatures in the United States or in Mexico, not through the forthright expression of a government willing to come clean about what interests it is pursuing in these talks and what the government's bottom line is and what it is negotiating for and on behalf of Canadians.
What can this government do to address this uncertainty which has shaken the confidence of Canadians so dramatically in recent months? Here I would refer to the motion that is before this House. I would argue that this government should be completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and objectives in the current North American free trade talks. Those are the words of the motion that is before this House today. It is an
March 24, 1992

expression of the absolute failure of this government with respect to these negotiations.
Surely this government can do this much to restore the faith of Canadians in their system of government by coming clean with their elected representatives and by telling the Canadian people through the Parliament of Canada what it is negotiating on behalf of Canadians and keeping Canadians informed every step of the way. That is the exact opposite of what this government has practised since the North American free trade negotiations were initially disclosed and discussed more than one year ago.
The government must begin to address those concerns which Canadians have about their own lives, those of their families and how this deal might impact on them. For instance, in this morning's Toronto Star it is reported that where the new North American free trade agreement is concerned, "there appears to be no specific protection provided in critical areas of the environment, health and safety standards and workers' rights".
Does this mean that Canadian workers will be competing against Mexican workers in the Maquiladora region who earn less than one dollar an hour and live as virtual economic slaves? Is this whom we will be competing against? Is this what Canadian workers will be faced with? It seems to be no longer a question of "if". There are already Canadian companies in Mexico taking advantage of these virtual slave labour conditions. Is this what rationalization means? Is this competitiveness?
Surely this government can indicate to Canadians today whether these standards will be tolerated in a North American free trade agreement. The answer should be self-evident. Yet, this government remains strangely silent. What exactly is going on with these negotiations?
On the environment, can our government not say that there will be no deal unless we receive commitments of environmental protective standards not only from the Mexicans but from the Americans as well? Surely this government can do no less.
What about agriculture? If I read the bracketed text of the North American free trade agreement, in agriculture it proposes that the agreement will call for allowing the Mexican government to subsidize the exporting of the production from these factory farms purchased by inves-

tors from Europe, Japan, the United States or any other country, land owned by small farmers in Mexico. The agreement will allow the Mexican government to subsidize the exporting of the production of these lands into the U.S. and into Canada. Effectively, this means that family farmers in these three countries would be seriously harmed under the terms that are in this proposed text.
Is this the text that the Canadian government is about ready to sign with the United States and with Mexico? At the same time, as they are preparing to negotiate, all the while protesting their fidelity to article XI of the GATT, they are preparing to say that Canadian supply management programs are effectively about to be abandoned to this Uruguay round.
In any case, the very least the government can do is let the people know that our interests, our standards of living will not be abandoned in the name of competitiveness and rationalization.

Mr. Speaker, I have listened with both interest and admiration to my distinguished friend who has developed some of the considerations involved in this debate with his usual skill and insight.
At the risk of some mild caricature, we have heard today one party, the government party, advance the proposition that everything is fine: "Trust us, the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement is a flawless agreement and equally the North American free trade agreement will bring immense benefit to Canadians". On the other end of the spectrum we have heard our colleagues from the New Democratic Party embrace their usual protectionist stance, looking for some sort of fortress Canada which does not actively seek export markets or engage in the challenges of globalism in both trade and investment.
Somewhere between those two extreme poles the member who has just spoken has developed a position which is worthy of some further discussion. I would seek his comment particularly on how this government has failed to act on providing the assistance to Canadians to accept the challenge of freer trade and to benefit from the reduction and removal of trade barriers around the

world. I would ask him whether he sees a need for active government involvement in providing the assistance to Canadians so that they can make a reality of a global trading environment.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank my distinguished colleague for his question and to compliment him on the contribution that he has made to defining a middle ground and a middle road for Canada in the pursuit of a trade policy.
Key to this middle road is active government intervention in order to enable Canadian firms and Canadians generally to be competitive on a global stage. We accept the phenomenon of the globalization of economic activity, but we are saying in this party that the federal government has a key role to play and an active role to play, for example, making sure that Canadians are trained and educated to meet the global challenge, that Canadians are not protected necessarily in the means of preventing them from adjusting, but that adjustment measures are in place to enable Canadians to transfer from occupations that become redundant as a result of moving toward more globalized trade and into activities that Canada may be able to benefit from.
Strangely enough the government promised with the free trade agreement between Canada and the U.S. that there would be generous adjustment mechanisms. We have not seen that. As a result, Canadians have found themselves without the proper training and without the proper adjustment assistance as we have paid the price, certainly in the first three years of massive adjustment, combined with a recession which has resulted in Canadians questioning whether or not this government is on its side in terms of preparing Canada for the economy of the future and I suppose contributing to general fears and protectionist sentiments which are growing around the world.
If the government is prepared to embark Canada on a more globalized trading footing, it has to take a responsibility to ensure that Canadians are ready to meet the challenges that lie ahead. That at the same time means that we are not, as the New Democratic Party is so quick to do, turning inward and sticking our heads in the sand and denying that we cannot have agreements with other countries. Surely we can. At the same time these agreements have to recognize environmental standards that must be maintained, that Canada and other countries must work toward health and safety standards, and
that our labour force has to be allowed to adjust to the new realities.
