speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the New Democrat government in British
Columbia has decided that women, not politicians, not hospital boards, will make decisions about the number and spacing of their children.
B.C. is funding clinics and ensuring that hospital boards cannot refuse to provide abortion services. It is providing $300,000 to support education and information on family planning. It has established a task force on access to contraception and abortion.
Sadly, some members of the Liberal, Conservative, and Bloc Quebecois do not agree. They clearly do not understand how important it is for Canadians to have the information and education they need to prevent unwanted pregnancies. These members deny women and men access to birth control information. Because of them, women will continue to need abortion services. These misguided members defeated Motion No. 44 on family planning.

subtopic: THE ENVIRONMENT
THE ENVIRONMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is now recognized throughout the world that the environment is everyone's concern and that all governments should assume their share of responsibility for it.
Here in Canada, the recent Supreme Court decision in the Oldman case reflected this state of affairs. What is even more important is to have the wisdom to realize that the environment goes beyond artificial geographic boundaries.
Bill C-13, the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, passed last Thursday by the House of Commons, is in tune with this new planetary consciousness which tells us that we must respect our physical surroundings and live in harmony with our environment.
With this new law, we will be able to take account of the foreseeable environmental consequences of our projects and activities and to make enlightened decisions in the spirit of sustainable development, which has become a world priority.

March 24, 1992

subtopic: THE ENVIRONMENT
THE ENVIRONMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on the first anniversary of the disastrous Exxon Valdez oil spill, it is fitting to remind ourselves of some basics. First, that the term "sustainable development" is more than just a slogan.
If governments mean what they say they have an obligation, now greater than ever, to prevent accidents, catastrophes, spills, overfishing, overcutting, over-farming, desertification, you name it, all the excesses our society has been prone to committing.
The Valdez oil spill, now a symbol with Love Canal, Bhopal, Chernobyl, reminds us that we have the capability to destroy the very foundation of our society, the environment, without resorting to nuclear arms.
While the threat of nuclear war is fading, the degradation of the environment continues. The transition to an environmentally sustainable world will not be easy, but it is the best option we have.

subtopic: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, March 21 was the international day for the elimination of racial discrimination. It was a day and is a day to promote racial harmony across our great nation. The theme "Together we are better" should be stressed in workplaces, communities, families, and in schools.
Though things are changing there are still many examples of discrimination occurring every day. For instance 90 per cent of placement agencies in this country are asked by clients to reject workers because of their skin colour. This is completely unacceptable.
Let us celebrate our differences while promoting equality for all. If we do not stop racism, who will?

subtopic: CAPE BRETON DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
CAPE BRETON DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Cape Breton pensioners' association has requested that the Cape Breton Development Corporation release information on retirement packages that are available to management and employee personnel.
The pensioners' association wants to utilize this information to make a case for the enhancement of benefits presently paid to retired employees who were not part of management.
Officials of the Cape Breton Development Corporation told the association that they will not be given this information and they should hire a lawyer if they want to obtain it.
The corporation is not covered under access to information, so it would seem that this group will have to undertake a lengthy legal procedure in order to obtain information that should be freely available.
Since this is not a matter of national security, I urge the minister responsible for the Cape Breton Development Corporation to instruct officials responsible for pension plans at the corporation to release this information. The workers have a right to know.

subtopic: THE ENVIRONMENT
THE ENVIRONMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Bill C-13, the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, was drafted to a large extent by Canadians themselves. They have clearly indicated that they want the federal government to change the way it conducts environmental assessments and to meet its responsibilities.
Three series of public consultations took place in the past four years. Bill C-13, adopted on third reading last week, responds directly to the needs and wishes expressed by those who came forward to give their opinions.
The new Canadian Environmental Assessment Act will give every one of us the opportunity to express our opinions on federal government decisions concerning developments that could change our lives and affect our environment for good or ill, in accordance with our commitment to sustainable development.
March 24, 1992

Constitutional questions must be settled at the constitutional table and environmental issues must be dealt with by the environment ministers.

subtopic: LOUIS RIEL
LOUIS RIEL
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the federal government has just recognized publicly Louis Riel's role as a founder of Manitoba. That is hypocritical and outrageous! The memory of Louis Riel is being used to promote constitutional reform.
Louis Riel struggled to give his people a country. He was driven out and hanged for that reason. On Saturday, March 15, I went to St. Boniface. I wanted to denounce the contemptuous attitude of the government, which uses a martyr's memory in such a low way. I am proud to belong to the same tradition as Louis Riel. I will never accept his name being used to manipulate Francophones and native people.

subtopic: DESTINY 92

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: DESTINY 92
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, earlier this month a successful career fair was held in Chilliwack.
Called "Destiny 92", it was hosted co-operatively by the Chilliwack Chamber of Commerce, the Chilliwack School District, the University College of the Fraser Valley, Canadian Forces Base Chilliwack, the Chilliwack Public Library and ECIC. This was Chilliwack's first ever career fair.
Large crowds of people of all ages attended. Many were young students while others were mature adults curious about a career change or upgrading. As well as displays by sponsors, there were displays from a variety of fields ranging from police, fire-fighting, trades, and significantly high tech and service industries. In short, if the job exists it was represented at this fair.
My encouragement goes out to those who attended to learn about career choices.
My congratulations go out to Roy McLoughlin and his committee of organizers for a job well done. Thank you
5. 0. 31
Cottenwood Shopping Mall for making the space available for this important career fair.

subtopic: DESTINY 92
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canadian gas producers have been keeping a nervous eye on the huge potential of the Mexican gas industry.
As Doig's Digest has noted: "Mexico's proved reserves, strategically located to interconnect with the Gulf Coast pipeline network linking Texas with U.S. markets, stand at 73 trillion cubic feet. In comparison, Canada has remaining marketable established gas reserves of 79 tcf, which includes 11 tcf in the Mackenzie Delta/Beaufort Sea area".
Mexico can produce in volumes, at prices, and with a proximity to markets which could place Canadian production, especially from frontier or difficult sources, at a severe disadvantage.
The government must do nothing, such as abandoning regulatory control of pipelines, that would throw our domestic market open to cheap Mexican gas. The result would be a devastation of the western and northern petroleum industry similar to that visited on Ontario manufacturing by the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement.

subtopic: SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH
SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, last Friday, the Hon. William Winegard, the Minister for Science, announced significant funding for the three federal granting councils.
The budgets for the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council, the Humanities Research Council and the Medical Research Council will increase by 4 per cent a year for the next four years. Funds for research and university training will thus increase by $321.5 million between 1992-93 and 1995-96. The new funds will give the councils the room they need to plan their activities and give more support to research and training.

March 24, 1992
Oral Questions
That is very positive for the scientific research community. It is another example of our government's efforts to stimulate scientific research.

subtopic: BREAST IMPLANTS
BREAST IMPLANTS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the days, months and years to come women implanted with potentially dangerous breast prostheses will come forward for help. They will ask that their implants be removed.
Dow Corning, the implant manufacturer, simply does not care what happens to Canadian women and has offered no money to help them. The federal minister of health says that the provinces should fund removal through our medicare system. But some provincial governments are unwilling to help.
In Manitoba the minister of health said that women with implants for enhancement purposes should seek removal costs from the manufacturer.
Canadian women trusted in this federal government when they assumed that the breast implants had been tested for safety prior to approval. Now they are caught in a tug of war involving the industry and federal and provincial governments.
I urge the minister of health, who guarantees the safety of these implants, to play a leadership role and assure Canadian women this government's lack of vigilance will not cost them another $3,000 when they seek to have these implants removed. Canadian women should not be made to suffer.

subtopic: TEACHERS' STRIKE
TEACHERS' STRIKE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, you and I know that any strike by Ottawa high school teachers is strictly a matter for the province of Ontario.
I am not taking sides in this fist-fight between the Ottawa Board of Education and its 1,000 teachers. But what worries me, what is filling the parents with doubts and fears is what should concern the federal government. What happens to those grade 12 and 13 students especially, who are caught in the middle of this dispute,
just as they are on the final approach to entrance requirements for university.
If the two sides in the OBE strike hunker down for a three to four week siege, I want the minister responsible for universities to alert those institutions that highly qualified, innocent victims need some special exemptions to carry on their education.
Surely, it is up to the federal government to help these young people to go on and build the Canada we all love.
['I know the hon. member is anxious about that and I will do everything I can to report to the House tomorrow.']

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister for International Trade.
For months we have been asking the government for progress reports on the negotiations between Canada, the United States and Mexico. Today, thanks to Action Canada, we were able to obtain documents that the government refuses to show to Canadians.
The document, which was prepared last year, contains 500 pages in which the economic future of all Canadians is hanging in the balance. Contrary to what the government told us, this document will take precedence over the agreement it signed a few years ago with the United States.
I wish the minister would tell me whether it is true this document will replace the free trade agreement we signed with the United States a few years ago.

I have listened very carefully to the hon. Leader of the Opposition and I am quite sure that he put some considerable thought into his question.
There is a debate going on today and I remind the House of the consideration of an opposition motion:
That this House condemn the government for its failure to be completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
The difficult task I have, on behalf of all of you, is to make sure that questions that are asked do not come within the wording of that motion.

I think the first question is acceptable, but I am asking hon. members to keep in mind carefully that I am bound by the rules as we all are.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first let me just put one of my hon. friend's comments in context. He said: "Where the economic future of all Canadians is hanging in the balance".
Trade with the Mexicans is about $2 billion or $2.5 billion which compares with our trade with the Americans of $256 billion, or the total size of our economy which is up in excess of $700 billion.
We should put this all in context. The specific question that my hon. friend has asked is whether a free trade agreement with Mexico would take precedence over the free trade agreement with the United States. The answer is no.
We have said on many, many occasions that if there are to be any changes to the free trade agreement with the United States that they would have to be improvements on that agreement. They would also require the agreement of both the Americans and ourselves.
My hon. friend can be assured that if there are going to be any changes to the free trade agreement with the United States, they will be very, very carefully reviewed and would only be agreed upon if they were improvements.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask another question of the minister. It is related to this new development that we have today.
It is a very comprehensive document that covers a lot of the areas that were covered before. In this document, it is indicated that the government decided many months ago that this deal with Mexico will be in place by January 1, 1993. At that time, this government, which does not have much legitimacy in Canada being at 12 per cent in the polls, will be in the fifth year of its mandate.
Will the minister give a guarantee to this country that the government will not sign this deal before we have an election in Canada?
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I should remind my hon. friend that his predecessor drove an election on free trade and did not do very well in it. I would talk to my hon. friend before jumping to that sort of conclusion.
Call an election, Mike.

speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
If it were my decision, maybe yes.
The question that my hon. friend has posed though is about the date for the coming into force of a free trade agreement including Mexico and the United States.
The date would be put in as an objective, but we have said all along that the timing for an agreement would be driven by the agreement. The agreement would not be driven by the timing.
We want to ensure that we get a good agreement. Depending on the timing of that agreement, it might come before or after an election. Who would know?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister has recognized that as far as he is concerned, he would rather have an election before.
In an election before, this time this government will be judged on what it has done. Last time, it was making promises. Now we know that it has not delivered, and Canadian workers are paying a terrible price for the free trade deal.
Will the minister tell his Prime Minister that if the government trusts the Canadian people, it will go to the people first. This time, you will be out of office.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me again put things in perspective here.
An election on a free trade agreement involving 75 per cent of our trade might have been an appropriate thing as the Leader of the Opposition and his predecessor had felt it would. But to have an election that is fought on the basis of less than 1 per cent of our trade surely is a bizarre suggestion.
Is my hon. friend suggesting that other economic issues, the issue of national unity and the issue of social policy are not important, that we should be fighting an election based on 1 per cent of our trade? That is ridiculous.

March 24, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, the health of the Canadian automotive sector which is central to our manufacturing base has rested largely on the auto pact.
It is now clear that the United States is demanding the elimination of the auto pact in the current trade negotiations with Mexico and Canada. Why is this government negotiating a trilateral agreement which does not preserve the terms of the auto pact?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I cannot understand the basis of my hon. friend's question.
We have said all along that our objective in this negotiation is to preserve the auto pact. Our objective is that if there is to be any change in the terms of the auto pact, it would be replaced by something that was equal to or better than the auto pact.
My hon. friend should also be aware that the reason automotive trade is on the table is that currently there are exports by Mexico into Canada of about $1.4 billion of automotive products. It is only $100 million the other way. The reason that is so is because of the auto decrees of the Mexicans which basically result in one-way free trade. They get access to our market duty free; we do not have access to their markets. One of our key objectives in the free trade agreement with the Mexicans is to get better access to their markets.

I see how
effective the automotive provisions of the free trade agreement are in the case of Honda. The minister knows perfectly well that in the current Honda dispute, the United States is exploiting the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement, and I use the Prime Minister's phrase, to harass Canadian exports. Moreover, it is no secret now that the United States is seeking higher content requirements in the current trade negotiations.
Can the minister tell the House why his government is negotiating an agreement that will make major changes to the rules of origin and content requirements for automobiles?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Honda problems and the problems with
CAMI have pointed out some clear problems with the interpretation of the rules of origin.
We have chapter 18 consultations under way under the free trade agreement to try to resolve that problem. We have set an objective, as I have said in the House on a number of occasions, of clarifying the rules of origin for a North American free trade agreement so that we would avoid the problem. That means setting the rules in advance and making sure that they are clearly understood and transparent so that we would avoid the problems we have now.

Mr. Speaker, following on the answer from the Minister for International Trade, should there be an election on the Mexico trade issue, we would hope that the Liberals' position was as clear as the last time when they ran in the election.
Referring to the draft text that the Leader of the Official Opposition spoke about today, my question to the Minister for International Trade is it appears in that document that Canada is now going for a system of tariffication on its small agricultural production in terms of supply management, eggs, poultry, et cetera. This is in direct contradiction to the government's statement that it was seeking to strengthen article XI.
Which is the position of Canada: the one in the draft agreement or the one stated by the government publicly? One was secret and one is public. Which one is accurate?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
First of all, let me draw some point of agreement between my hon. friend and myself.
The position of members of the Liberal Party in the last election was clear. They opposed the agreement. Right now, it is not clear and I think my hon. friend and I would agree on that. They say they would renegotiate. They do not say what they would renegotiate. If they cannot renegotiate, they do not say they know what they would do. So it is a little bit of a shell game by the Leader of the Opposition.
I wanted to respond specifically to the question of my hon. friend on agricultural objectives in the NAFTA as it related to the supply managed sector.
March 24, 1992

The position, as I stated in the House just a few days ago, is that we are seeking clarification and strengthening of article XI in the multilateral trade negotiations. That position is identical as far as the negotiations with the Mexicans and the Americans are concerned.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the minister for answering the first part of my question and leaving us all in confusion about who is answering for the Liberals but, nonetheless, we will wait for that.
My second question concerns the draft NAFTA agreement. There are further threats to Canadian jobs in the generic drug industry, textiles, telecommunications, auto parts, transport and now we are looking at new threats in the energy sector.
I ask the minister this question and I have asked it before. Has the government done any impact studies on these areas that I have mentioned and, if so, is the government prepared to release those impact studies so Canadian citizens can see exactly what we are facing in this agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend has raised five specific industries. I think my hon. friend is also well aware that the results of the NAFTA are not known. We do not know what the end result will be in these five areas.
I can tell my hon. friend our objectives. I would be happy to go through these one by one if my hon. friend would come to committee and ask me these questions. Then I could provide him with our specific negotiating objective, as I have been prepared to do at previous meetings, but my hon. friend has not been prepared to ask those types of questions.
Mr. Speaker, I asked for the impact studies, not for conversation.
Oh, oh.

It appears in the document that has been presented publicly as the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free trade draft bracketed agreement that there will be an assault on provincial sovereignty.
I want to ask the minister if he is prepared, under that agreement, to shift any of the authority of the provinces
Oral Questions
to control their own resources. Specifically I want to ask about peeler logs and chips. Is it the position of the Government of Canada that if it signs an agreement with the United States and Mexico that the provincial governments would no longer have the authority to control the export of whole logs, chips or peeler logs from their respective jurisdictions?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TFade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have two comments on my friend's question.
My friend referred to a draft bracketed text and that makes my point for me, because it is a draft text. It has the views of three countries reflected in it. It is bracketed. It means the words that are in brackets are not agreed upon. So the document that my hon. friend is referring to is a very preliminary document.
The position on matters that relate to the resource policies of the provincial governments will only be decided in full consultation with the provinces themselves. At this point there is no proposal at all to make any changes in the export of logs.
My hon. friend is well aware that we have weekly discussions with the provinces on all aspects of the agreements and it is on that basis that our policies are developed.

Mr. Speaker, this report is not about scoring cheap political points at the expense of the Liberal Party. The NDP did not understand that in the last election and apparently still do not understand it.
What is at stake here is the future of Canada. I was pleased to hear the minister responsible for trade say in this House that he personally would like to see an election. Unfortunately, his document shows that his government is trying to ram this deal through before we have a chance to go to the people.
Given the minister's comments in the House today, will he make a recommendation to the Prime Minister of Canada that no deal be signed until we go to the Canadian people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend reminds me of a statement made in the 1984 election-there she goes again. Time and time again, my hon. friend stands up and distorts what I have just said about five or ten minutes ago in this

March 24, 1992
Oral Questions
House. I never said that there should be an election. I said maybe that is an idea, but I did not support it.
What I did say is let us put this into context. Why would we call an election simply on one issue, an issue that is related to 1 per cent of our trade and a good deal less than the size of our economy, when there are so many other issues.
But what I do wish to ask the hon. member, if she is so anxious to get into a debate on trade, when is the Liberal Party going to state what it would renegotiate? And if it cannot renegotiate, what is its position going to be? Are we going to have it ripped up again?
The minister is not here to ask questions. Right now you are here to answer them.
Oh, oh.
I am sure the hon. member can put her question in a more polite form.

Mr. Speaker, the minister keeps saying that this document has no connection with trade with the Americans and Mexico. In fact, the document discusses free trade in telecommunications, a position that is not shared by this government.
My question for the minister is this: Considering that this document will wipe out farmers in Quebec and across Canada and that it supports tariffication of our agricultural products, unlike the policy announced publicly by this government, is the minister prepared to recommend that a federal election should be held before the document is endorsed?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, clearly my question to the hon. member struck a raw nerve end. I do not think she wants to talk about the trade policy of the Liberal Party.
My hon. friend referred to telecommunications. This is a proposal that has come from the Americans. But just
because they put forward a proposal, does that mean we have accepted it? No, we have rejected it.
My hon. friend raises a question concerning farmers. She waves the text in front of us. I have not seen a copy of the text. I have not seen that document. That may be the Liberals' policy on pharmaceuticals in 1969 for all I know.

Mr. Speaker, in the document in the section on agriculture, under heading "Canadian Proposal" it says that we are provided for. Tariff equivalency resulting from conversion of non-tariff barriers shall be reduced in accordance with the schedule under the proposed agreement on the Uruguay round.
How could the minister let his colleague, the Deputy Prime Minister, go in front of 20,000 farmers, swear that this government would fight to the last breath tariffication, when this minister had already given away the store, the farm and the country under the NAFTA proposal?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, there is no giving away the store, the farm and the country, that my hon. friend huffs and puffs about. We have not made any proposal in that direction at all. That is not the Canadian position.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the minister. This is the man who wants to be trusted but who gave us the free trade agreement that betrayed every single trust of Canadians because they have lost their jobs.
I want to ask this question. Why is this government making the same mistake twice? Why in this proposal are we agreeing to a dispute settlement mechanism which has no subsidy code to it, therefore once again making Canadians vulnerable to U.S. trade law, to U.S. harassment, to U.S. intimidation, under a new deal that will give no help whatsoever in solving disputes?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend and I have a fundamental disagreement on the free trade agreement with the United States. My hon. friend ignores the fact that
March 24, 1992

exports are up under the free trade agreement with the United States, in spite of the fact that we have a recession in the United States. My hon. friend neglects the fact that the trade surplus between Canada and the United States is up 10 per cent again in spite of the recession in the United States.
There have been benefits. I can give my friend a list of companies which have been major beneficiaries. I can give my friend a list of industries that have been major beneficiaries of the free trade agreement with the United States.
My hon. friend talks about the fact that we do not have a subsidy agreement. We do have a subsidy agreement in the Uruguay round negotiations, in the Dunkel paper that was brought forward on December 20 last year. It is our intention and it is agreed upon that if that is what is the final agreement on the Uruguay round, it will be transferred to the free trade agreement with the United States and I would expect that to be the case with the free trade agreement with Mexico as well.

Mr. Speaker, I want to remind the Minister for International Trade that while trade between Canada and Mexico may be 1 per cent, trade between Canada and the United States is much greater. It is that aspect that we are really concerned about.
My question for the Minister of Transport deals with Canadian Annex 402.1 transportation services, which states that land transportation services, like truck, bus, rail transportation, land site aspects of port activities, freight forwarding, customs brokerage and maintenance and repair of commercial land transportation equipment are given up under the North American free trade agreement. As the minister knows, all of these sectors are vulnerable. They cannot even compete today.
I want to ask him, as the minister responsible for protecting transportation in this country, how he can allow such an agreement to be written.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International IVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I remind my friend that any of the negotiating positions we are putting forward in the NAFTA are developed with the provinces and with the industries concerned.
Oral Questions
In this case we believe that if we are going to be trading between Canada and Mexico and using our truck transportation services to move the product, surely we want to give our trucking industry the same benefits as their competition. That is what we are trying to achieve. That is the objective that we have in the negotiations, so we can keep the trucks full of cargo going from Canada down to Mexico and back.

Mr. Speaker, I want to remind the Minister for International Trade that almost a year ago we had truckers parked on Parliament Hill, we had truckers parked on bridges connecting Canada and the U.S.A. because they said at that time that they could not compete and they wanted a better deal.
I want to put my question to the Minister of Transport who has responsibility for transportation in this country. How can this government give up our trucking industry, our rail industry and all of our other service industries, including land site activities of ports. We know that if they cannot compete today without a free trade agreement, they are not going to be able to compete if there is one. They are going to go down the tubes. They are going to go south of the border. You have got to stop it.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for Internationa] TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend does not acknowledge in his question the fact that we have responded. We have dealt with a number of the questions that the truckers expressed to us when they were here on Parliament Hill.
My colleague, the Minister of Finance, put forward a package of proposals which touched on excise taxes on fuel, on capital cost allowances and a number of other factors which have improved the competitive position of the Canadian trucking industry.
My hon. friend is wrong when he says that the Canadian trucking industry cannot compete internationally. They can compete internationally. One of the problems that they do have is high provincial excise taxes on fuel. They will not have that in the United States when they are going through the United States to Mexico and we believe that they can compete.

Mr. Speaker, this government is planning to give away, through this trilateral agreement, Canadian control of a key economic lever and a regional development tool. I am talking about our telephone industry.

March 24, 1992
Oral Questions
Why is this government allowing American telephone companies, like AT&T, access to waltz in and dominate these new evolving telephone services. The Canadian people would like to know why the government is surrendering this strategic Canadian sector.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the simple answer is we are not. The American industry can make proposals to get into our basic telephone system. We have said no.
She asks what about the enhanced industiy. In the enhanced sector of the telecommunications industry, the major value-added products, the Canadian industry is a world leader. Surely she should be on my back saying: "We have to get access to the U.S. market. We have to get access to the Mexican market for enhanced telecommunications because we are world leaders there. We can compete. There is extremely good business for us there".

Mr. Speaker, I would suggest to the minister that Canadians want to make the decisions for themselves and they want Canadian ownership of their Canadian properties.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to speak today on the topic of North American free trade. It gives members of Parliament and the Canadian public a better chance to understand the deal, as difficult as that may be, given the secretive nature of the negotiations.
I wonder where the cabinet is today and where they have been on this issue. Other than the Minister of Forestry, no other member of the cabinet has spoken on this issue today, or even been here so far for the debate. Given the importance of this deal, I cannot see what could be more important for these ministers than to
March 24, 1992

stand up in public today and explain to Canadians why we should support a North American free trade deal.
The government is hoping to conclude the deal by next month and is rushing through the negotiations. As a result, the majority of Canadians have no idea what is going on. Certainly we all have the right to know. The House of Commons Standing Committee on External Affairs and International Trade, in its report to Parliament entitled "North American Free Trade", said quite clearly it wanted the Canadian government to consult with Canadians on this issue.
I do not believe this government has responded adequately to the House of Commons call for this request. For instance, I doubt many Canadians realize that a deal reached with the three countries will have major implications for agriculture in this country. Obviously much time and effort has gone into pressuring the government to ensure that our system of supply management is maintained. This is essential to any country that wishes to secure a supply of food for itself.
We have been under international pressure, namely American pressure, to do away with our border protection and supply management.
The importance of a viable Canadian farming sector centres around the ability of a nation to produce its food and secure its supply of food for the present and the future.
Sovereignty and nationalism are inextricably linked to the ability of any nation to feed its people. Without a viable Canadian farming sector there can be no food security for Canadians. This is in danger in these negotiations.
Obviously there is a lot at stake both in Geneva and now at the NAFTA negotiations. In both instances Canadian agriculture is on the bargaining table. Frankly, farmers in this country do have a reason to be worried.
Although we have been given assurances by the government that it will stand by its promise to strengthen article XI of GATT, we know the importance it is placing on reaching GATT and NAFTA agreements. Once again agriculture is at the centre of the negotiations and in fact an obstacle, as some say, to a successful deal.
The Americans are insisting we move to a system of tariffication and end supply management in this country.
Supply
Given the argument I have just made for the deal, this is potentially dangerous for our agrifood sector in Canada and for Canadian farmers.
Before we rush into another agreement, the government must face some of the facts about the free trade agreement we presently have with the United States. First and foremost, the government must recognize that the free trade deal is not providing secure access to the American market as it was originally intended to do. The dispute mechanism is laughable. It is certainly not a genuine shield against American protectionism. Softwood lumber and Honda automobiles are prime examples of this. We need fair trade rules now. How can we possibly enter into a new trade agreement with so much going wrong with the present one?
What about the impact of the new agreement on the Canadian public and economy? These questions need to be answered. A federal government document indicated there was much to be lost. In fact, it said it could cost jobs and undermine some of our cultural industries. In my reading, the document shows there would be very little Canadian gain, if any.
This government desperately wants a deal, so we are naturally concerned the government would be willing to sign a potentially flawed deal just to get one. Parliament is being denied a chance to examine this proposed North American free trade agreement. We have to find copies of it in little brown envelopes just to find out what is going on in the deal. Even though the American and Mexican legislators have already been briefed, there has been no similar briefing done here. It has been leaked to many newspapers across the country, including the Toronto Star and we still know nothing about this deal. The lack of cabinet involvement in this debate just underscores this point.
We do not even know what the government's minimal objectives are. We need questions answered. What are the economic costs and benefits to Canada? Will this government be part of a trilateral agreement which does not include a subsidy code and or a prompt and binding dispute mechanism?. Canadians have a right to know. Canadians have a right to know what the government plans to do with the snap-back mechanism which would permit tariffs to be phased out over a period of time if dumping occurs.

March 24, 1992
Supply
Any agricultural package that does not include a snap-back provision between Canada and the other two countries will certainly help to dismantle the Canadian horticultural industry. How can domestic producers of fresh fruits and vegetables possibly be protected should import prices drop dramatically?
Certainly this is a real threat, given the climate and lower labour costs in Mexico which will allow them to be competitive in a North American market.
What about the inclusion of other countries? Has this government regarded the possible formation of a North and South American free trade area? Canadians have a right to know. The Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement did not include any rules for a third country, such as Mexico, jumping in. That is why we are having the debate today. We do not have the so-called preferential access the government here claimed during the last election and which it has claimed over the last few years. What will the cost be to Canada? Where is Canada's so-called preferential treatment? What is the government doing about a subsidy code? What is it doing on a dispute mechanism that will be prompt and binding? When is the government going to share with us in any meaningful way what is going on in these negotiations?
Earlier in the week, the minister said this is commercially confidential information. We do not want commercially confidential information. We want to know what is going on in the negotiations and what the government's bottom lines are. Canadians want an assurance from this government that it will not, once again, sell them out at the negotiating table.
The one thing for sure is that everything is apparently back on the table in these negotiations. Once again, after we have given a little here and a little there, we will end up with another flawed agreement. In other words we will end up with nothing, so let us do ourselves a favour. Let us get these basic questions answered first before we, once again, sign on the dotted line and sign our country away. Let us just think about it.

I want to participate in the debate today because of what I have now learned is in the draft NAFTA agreement. The motion before us condemns the government for its lack of openness and failure to ensure Canadians had access to the draft agreement so they could make some knowledgeable decisions to help put pressure on the government for particular changes. Having read the Canadian annex 402.1, dealing with transportation services, I can understand why they did not want the Canadian public through their MPs to know. It is horrendous.
I want to read some sections because they make me very angry and I think they will make Canadians in the
Supply
transportation sector even angrier because it is their jobs that are on the line.
Annex 402.1, that is the Canadian version, called chapter 14 for the Mexican version and 05.1 A for the American version, says that "this annex shall apply to all measures of a party related to the provision of land transportation services by a national or other party. For purposes of this annex, land transportation services means: (1) truck transportation, (2) bus transportation, (3) rail transportation, (4) landside aspects of port activities, (5) freight forwarding, (6) customs brokerage, (7) warehousing except for those activities covered by chapter", whatever it is called, "financial services: (8) maintenance and repair of commercial land transportation equipment, (9) pipeline operations except for those covered by the energy chapter, and (10) courier services".
That is a very comprehensive list. The only thing that is not on the list is air. As we speak, just down the road at the Chateau the Government of Canada and the Government of the United States are working on a bilateral air agreement which will in effect deregulate air travel between Canada and the U.S.
This agreement as drafted, and I am not exaggerating when I say this, will mean the end of a Canadian based transportation system for road, for rail, road for both trucking and bus. The sheer economies of scale will dictate that it is more efficient to locate the head office, the main branches, whether it is rail or the main routes or what have you, the hubs, in the United States, serving both Canada and Mexico.
We saw that kind of pressure between Canada and the United States certainly a year go when the truckers parked their vehicles outside the House of Commons, tied up traffic in downtown Ottawa for a number days and also in Windsor and other border crossings where they literally blocked access between Canada and the United States. They pointed out rightfully how unlevel the playing field was. Whether it was because of fuel taxes, whether it was because of write-offs, and I do not care whether it is federal responsibility or provincial responsibility, the bottom line was they could not compete.

There were American truckers loading up their products, filling up their gas tanks just south of the border, travelling all the way to Montreal to drop off then-products, turning around and going back and in some cases having to be topped up by jerry cans while on the top of the bridge on the international crossing. That is unfair competition.
The minister in the House earlier today said: "But we did things for them, so therefore it is okay". Yes, they did. They gave them some tax breaks in terms of the write-offs. They also gave them some breaks on the 4 cents per litre excise fuel tax. In effect, what they have done though through NAFTA is tear up all those items of assistance that will no longer be allowable under NAFTA if this agreement were ever to be approved.
Why am I so concerned? Let me go back to when this country was formed and the reason that we developed a rail infrastructure that went east-west rather than north-south. Sir John A. Macdonald knew that if we did not have those linkages from east to west, we would very quickly be gobbled up by the United States of America. It would have made more sense to run a railway from Thunder Bay down into the Chicago area, to run a railway from B.C. down the Pacific coast, to run a railway from Toronto down to Buffalo and points south. We never would have had a country. But the reality of 1867 is the reality of today. If we do not have those east-west transportation links owned and operated and maintained and managed by Canadians, we are not going to have a country.
This agreement in effect gives American railroads the right to come and operate on our tracks. It gives American trucking companies the right to come and operate on our roads. It gives American companies the right to come in and handle our cargoes in our ports. They cannot really touch the ships but as soon as it is on land, they can do everything else.
In fact I would like to read one of the American proposals into the record. "The U.S. has proposed that such activities will include the operation and maintenance of docks, loading and unloading of vessels, marine cargo handling, operation and maintenance of piers, ship cleaning, stevedoring, transfer of cargo between ships and trucks, trains, pipelines and wharfs, waterfront terminal operations, boat cleaning, canal operation"- canal operation? Are they going to take over the seaway locks and operate them?-"dismantling of ships, operation of marine railways for drydocking, marine surveyors"-except cargo-"marine wrecking, ships for scrap, and ship classification societies".
That is what the Americans want included in the North American free trade agreement. If this Government of Canada ever says yes then you will see thousands of jobs in the maritime sector taken away from Canadians and given to Americans and eventually given to Mexicans. That is unacceptable. As a society and a country we cannot tolerate that kind of change.
I should point out, Mr. Speaker, that I am sharing my time with my colleague. If you would give me the ten-minute notice so we can go into the five-minute question and comment then I will turn it over to my colleague.
There is another aspect I want to raise and again this is a proposal from the Americans. I realize I have just two minutes.
We went through a major debate in this House in this country over whether or not we should control transportation through regulations. The government of the day followed what the Liberals started before them and went for deregulation. Instead of the old means test of whether it met the test of public convenience and necessity, i.e. an economic test, we went for something else.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today we are debating the proposed North American free trade agreement between Canada, the United States and Mexico.
I take the position that this deal is not in the best interests of Canada and in fact can do more harm than good, given the circumstances of the political situation, the bargaining position of the three countries and the differing political institutions that exist in each of the countries.
We have only to go back a few years and look at the negotiations between Canada and the United States to reinforce why I am concerned about some of these problems. Canada and the U.S. had their negotiations. Canada is about one-tenth or one-eleventh the size of the United States. The bargaining positions of the two countries showed in the agreement. Politically the United States is a superpower, but of more importance, in negotiating international agreements with them, is their quite different constitution and their very much different attitude on the powers of Congress and the powers of the President.
Our government went into the negotiations with the naive assumption that the President of the United States spoke for his country in a manner not unlike the way the Prime Minister of our country speaks for this country. That is patently untrue and impossible.
The U.S. Congress holds the rights carefully to its bosom to change trade law and to be responsible ultimately for any international agreement that the United States President and his administration might attempt to negotiate.
Our negotiators, our government in particular, did not seem to be aware of what that means in the long term.
Some of us from western Canada that have dealt on a so-called free trade basis with the Americans understood how it worked. We have traded in red meats, beef and hogs for 50 years under a so-called free trade agreement. Any time we start to make inroads into their markets in a way that has a definite economic advantage to Canada, ways and means are found in the Congress of the United States to make certain that trade does not continue at the same pace. So there have always been interruptions to that trade.
After we signed the trade agreement, which the government and its proponents said would forever and ever do away with that kind of dispute problem, immediately we were faced with a pork countervail which has been resolved for the moment, but the resolution of that countervail is still in some doubt. American congressmen and American pork producers are still convinced that because two of the people involved in the countervail action had some doubts about whether American law was being adhered to, the whole process will begin again as soon as the price rises enough to make it worth while for American producers to block the shipments of Canadian pork into that country.
The phrase "according to U.S. law" is something we will have to get used to if we are going to be dealing with so-called free trade agreements with the Americans, whether it is on a bilateral basis, Canada-U.S., or a trilateral basis with Mexico, Canada and the United States.
Essentially Congress will not give up, and has every constitutional right not to give up, the right to permit any president, whether it is President Bush or Reagan or any successor, to give away by international treaty that right. It can be worded as clearly as we like in the agreement that Canada and Mexico or any other country might want to sign, but ultimately Congress can overrule that and whenever there is a dispute, ultimately it is U.S. law that must be adhered to, not the agreement.
As long as we get the ground rules straight, we will have a good ball game. We will also know that because those are the rules we will probably lose most of the innings but we will have a good ball game as long as we understand that. Unfortunately this Prime Minister and this government do not seem to understand what the rules of the ball game are.
March 24, 1992

We have seen some drafts now, thanks to U.S. freedom of information laws and the propensity of Americans to be able to get information. We also had information from some of the people in Mexico as to what was being discussed.
We could not rely on our own government to supply this kind of information. We had to go overseas to find out just what our country is saying at these talks and what we have agreed to.
Until February 21 or 22, it appears that Canada's negotiating position on agriculture, which I will speak about for a couple of minutes, was pretty much the same negotiating position that it took into the international talks at the Uruguay round starting in 1986, which was and continued to be until some time during 1990 or 1991, a policy of transferring all subsidies and all government interventions in agriculture into a tariff, in other words, tariffication.
Once again, as it was in Uruguay and in the NAFTA, this business of seeking tariffication is the official Government of Canada position. That is unfortunate because at home, under pressure from dairy producers and producers of poultry and eggs that realize that this is the death knell to their commodity production in Canada, the government is saying at GATT that that was not really its position.
It changed it some time in 1990 or 1991, and there is some paper to show that there was a memo sent at that period of time at GATT. So far, there does not seem to be any paper saying that Canada's position on tariffication is any different, except as a hard line tariffication proposal under the NAFTA.
The dairy people, the poultry people and the egg people are once again being forgotten in the negotiations because the government is following a clear, hard line tariffication stance. It is a clear, hard line that suits an economic development model that is dependent on the corporations doing all of the development, but it is not
Supply
one that fits very well the purposes of ordinary Canadians.
We have thousands and millions of people in Canada who are small business people from farmers to retailers, wholesalers and even small manufacturers. They are not covered by that kind of policy. They are left out. It is presumed they do not matter, that they cannot be globally competitive, which is the watchword or catchword that this government is attempting to follow.
Canadian farmers and small business people will be relegated to the same position that the Mexican peasant will be relegated to if the Mexican government gets its way, which is to make it possible to sell land to international corporations for agricultural development.
That may sound like a fairly innocuous matter when you live way up here, several thousand miles from Mexico, but that country has had several revolutions over those lands that are held in the name of the country of Mexico for the use of thousands and millions of Mexican peasant farmers who have no other access to land. That is their right.
It was fought for several times in several revolutions and this is the only land that the Government of Mexico has available for sale to foreign corporations.
The current Government of Mexico seems intent upon following a policy similar to this government of selling all of its assets. It appears that farmland is going to be one of those assets. The result will be very cheap land to international corporations which will probably sell fruits and vegetables into the more northern parts of North America.
As farmers in this part of the world, we will be hard pressed to continue producing fruits and vegetables at all because of an agreement that is not a fair agreement. It is set out to purposely get rid of small producers, small business people so that a theory of international control can prevail.
We do not think this is fair or practical. It makes no sense economically. It makes even less sense to people who believe in democratic principles. We think it is time these 500 pages were trashed and the negotiations ceased immediately.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure today to take part in this debate. I am
delighted to be able to talk about the way this government has deliberately and conscientiously sought the views of a broad cross-section of Canadians on trade policy questions.
Contrary to opposition claims, Canadians' views have been critical of the way in which the government has pursued the North American free trade agreement involving Canada, the United States and Mexico. The opposition wishes to cancel Canadian involvement in NAFTA negotiations.
Hon. members opposite contend that the government has shut Canadians out of the process. In holding this view, they are frankly strangely oblivious to the well organized, carefully planned and thoroughly detailed set of consultations with Canadians that this government has undertaken for more than six years. I regret the opposition's belated awakening to the importance of the North American free trade negotiations.
If they had examined the initiative earlier, hon. members would have been aware of the extensive consultations that have taken place to date. Still, the debate today allows me to outline just how thorough that process has been.
The government has in place a broad and strong network of advisers that has helped us develop our national strategy. The heart of this network is the International Trade Advisory Committee, or ITAC. It is made up of representatives of business, labour organizations, the academic and research communities, consumers, cultural industries and environmental groups.
Its role is to provide a two-way flow of information and advice between the government and the Canadian private sector. In addition to ITAC there are 15 sectoral advisory groups on international trade, known in verbal shorthand as SAGITs.
The SAGITs bring together business, labour, academics, researchers, consumers and environmentalists who are involved in specific sectors of the Canadian economy ranging from the agrifood sector to transportation services. These groups serve as vehicles for the two-way flow of information and advice between the government and particular industrial sectors. The SAGITs are influential in themselves, but the chair of each SAGIT also sits on ITAC, which further enhances their role.
March 24, 1992

This network was not dreamed up yesterday; it was established in 1985 to provide advice for the negotiations for the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. It continued and still maintains a crucial advisory role in the Uruguay round of multilateral trade negotiations under the GATT, and its assistance has been invaluable in the negotiations toward NAFTA.
ITAC first examined the subject of a NAFTA in 1990 as the government began to consider whether to enter into the three-way negotiations with the United States and Mexico. So hon. members can see that the government had the benefit of its advice in choosing to join the NAFTA. It is a decision that we made in February of
1991.
ITAC meets regularly with the hon. Minister for International Trade, as often as four times a year. The last meeting was in December. Many of the SAGITs meet more frequently still. Some individual SAGITs have discussed NAFTA more than half a dozen times since the actual negotiations began last June in Toronto.
The assistance of ITAC and the SAGITs has not only been useful, it has been vital. With 19 working groups within the negotiations examining often highly technical details, the government's negotiators simply cannot afford to be without expert advice. The government knows full well that for the members of the SAGITs trade is not abstract theory. Trade is their livelihood and trade policy helps to determine their future.
The government has undertaken this consultation process because it is aware of this awesome responsibility. The interests of all participants in the Canadian economy must be carefully taken into account.
Let me stress that these advisory bodies are not representative of business only. Labour, academics, researchers, consumer groups, representatives of cultural industries, and environmentalists all are also active.
The government was particularly pleased when the Canadian Labour Congress decided to join ITAC after the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement in 1989. It was unfortunate that government was unable to benefit from the CLC's wide experience and knowledge during the original free trade agreement negotiations. We were thankful for the participation of the Canadian Federation of Labour which represents an important group of
Supply
Canadian workers, especially in the important construction industry.
But a truly representative advisory network needs the involvement of the organization that represents the majority of Canadian organized labour. Although the CLC has been vigorous in putting forward its views, the government believes labour's involvement in ITAC and the participation of CLC-affiliated unions in the SAGITs represent a significant step forward to co-operate in economic decision-making.
The participation of the academic community has given positive direction to the consultations. Canadians are becoming increasingly aware of the need to adapt our education to meet the requirements of a fast-evolving global economy. Canadians also recognize that today's knowledge-intensive industries must find effective ways to turn scientific breakthroughs in laboratories into products and services in the marketplace.
In ITAC and the SAGITs educators can gauge the requirements for development of new skills. At the same time, the government can tailor its trade policy to effectively employ the skills and knowledge that educators have so carefully fostered.
The part of the consultation process that has been least noticed, I believe, is the inclusion of environmental representatives on the ITAC and many of the SAGTIk. In keeping with the government commitment to take environment into account in major policy initiatives, it was vital that environmental groups be involved in the examination of the NAFTA.
Since the negotiations began, many commentators have raised the environment as an important issue for the NAFTA negotiations. The government agrees.
That is why the agreement will ensure that any of the signatory countries can maintain product health and safety standards superior to international norms.
That is why the government has formed an interdepartmental committee to review the potential environmental impact of a NAFTA on Canada. That is why Canada has increased its environmental co-operation with Mexico announcing last week a $1 million agreement to assist Mexico in improving its environmental enforcement.

March 24, 1992
Supply
That is one reason environmental representatives have been members of ITAC and the SAGITs since last fall. Their contributions have been most constructive and the government is hoping that this new relationship will be productive for all concerned.
Through the contributions of environmental representatives on ITAC and the SAGITs, the government will receive objective advice to ensure that NAFTA and other trade policies effectively take environmental issues into consideration.
The modern economy increasingly needs close co-operation among all participants in the economy. The consultation that now takes place in relation to the NAFTA negotiations is one solid example of that. This process has won the approval of independent observers who have commented on this contribution toward greater co-operation among Canadian economic sectors.
In a study of ITAC and the SAGITs, Helen Moroz, a professor of political studies at Queen's University had this to say and I quote:
The systematic consultation between the private sector and the government appears to have enhanced the over-all attitudes among the different interests toward one another. Regular contact and the sharing of information proved to establish an understanding and trust between the participants-The process has paved the way for co-operative private sector/govemment consultation on trade-related and other matters in the future.
Perhaps not all members of the House favour closer economic co-operation to improve the functioning of the Canadian economy, but the government believes that such co-operation and the development of new strategic partnerships among all participants in the economy are keys to Canada's future competitiveness.
Closer co-operation which will in turn encourage more imaginative approaches to economic decision-making will contribute in the end to greater prosperity for all Canadians.
Hon. members of the opposition complain that these consultations do not take place in public, that yet again the government is conducting public business behind closed doors. However, the quiet nature of these discussions does not worry the members of ITAC and SAGITs. I cannot speak for all of them but the confidentiality to which they have sworn themselves provides them the opportunity to be candid and express their views without worrying that they will be heard by the United States, Mexican, or even Japanese or European competitors.
The value of advice often rests on the frankness with which it can be given.
When the government knows it is hearing the honest unvarnished views of the private sector, it is better able to act in the interests of all concerned.
I have to stress that even if the opinions expressed in ITAC and the SAGITs meetings do not make headlines, they are being heeded. The opposition charges that the public is not being consulted. But look at the list of the sectors represented by SAGIT: agriculture, food and beverages, apparel and footwear, arts and cultural industries, consumer and household products, energy, chemicals and petrochemicals, financial services, fish and fish products, forest products, industrial and high-technology equipment, minerals and metals, business and professional services, textiles, fur and leather, transportation equipment, transportation services.
I am not trying to bore honourable members. I am only trying to point out that these consultations involve nearly every conceivable corner of the Canadian economy.
The ITAC and the SAGITs do more than bring together the different industrial sectors. They also link the economic factors from one end of the production line to the other, from extraction of raw materials, processing and manufacturing, to transportation, marketing and sales.
These advisory bodies are cross-sectors of Canadian society. They include representatives of small businesses and large. They include members from small towns and big cities. They bring together people from every region of the country. They include francophones and anglophones. There are women and men. There is no sector, barely a comer of productive activity or any region of the country or any job in the private sector in Canada that is not covered in one way or another by one of these sectoral advisory groups and the International Trade Advisory Committee.
These bodies are also constantly being refreshed. The government is continuously reviewing membership to ensure it appropriately represents the changing face of the Canadian economy. An ITAC and a SAGIT member's term is two years. In making the appointments the government strives to ensure an effective mixture of new blood and experience. New ideas are always vital to the consultation process. So also is continuity to ensure that what has been learned in the past is preserved and put to good use.

March 24, 1992

When the government announced the formation of the ITAC and the SAGER consultation process more than six years ago, it was undertaking a major new initiative in communications between the public and the private sectors. The government had a plan that it knew was a good plan. But it could not have known how much the advisory network would be challenged and how it would respond. It responded well and effectively.
With the advice we continue to receive from these advisory groups, we will be able to negotiate a North American free trade agreement that serves the interests of all Canadians. When Canadian negotiators go to the bargaining table they are fully aware of the concerns and the ambitions of all sectors of the Canadian economy. That is the best guarantee that a North American free trade agreement, if it can be achieved, will reflect the interests and the ambitions of Canadians across the land.
This government is committed to consultations. Without consultations we simply could not negotiate a North American free trade agreement or pursue a trade policy of any kind. Government does not work in a vacuum. It must be aware of the needs and interests of the community at large. To do this, there is no substitute for a process of close and continuous dialogue. That dialogue, so effectively represented by the ITAC and the SAGER process will continue.
