subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is an honour to speak on my party's motion which condemns the government for its failure to be completely open with Canadians about its plans, its goals and objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
Trade issues are of utmost importance to Canadians, certainly western Canadians. In large measure our country was built on our exportability. It is what drives the economy of much of our land and many thousands of our fellow citizens.
Yet trade is an area of public policy about which the people of Canada know less than we might. It is not because we are ignorant of its impact on our economy or our social fabric. It is not because we would rather leave these decisions to officials.
Canadians know less about trade than we ought to because this government likes it that way. It fooled many of us once before in the debate over the free trade agreement with the United States and now it wants to hoodwink the people of Canada again over the North American free trade, NAFTA.
All of us in this House are familiar with the old adage: "You can fool some of the people some of the time". Canadians will not be fooled again.
Request after request to the government to inform the House on behalf of 27 million Canadians on the progress of the NAFTA talks has been met with rejection. Such divulging would threaten the talks, they say. "Trust us. We know what is good for Canada."
My colleague for Etobicoke North has risen on numerous occasions to ask the Minister for International Trade for details on the progress of the negotiations. He has asked him for a copy of the bracketed agreement now in circulation, as my colleague from Mount Royal said a minute ago, leaked through Ralph Nader in Washington.
He along with many more on this side of the House have asked the government for even the most general of statements about progress on such items as human rights. Mexico's record on human rights, Mr. Speaker, is not what you and I would want it to be, nor in my view on democracy either, environmental standards, health and safety and the like.
No answers have been forthcoming. It seems that the government is not willing to address these issues until after the deal is done and ready to be rammed through this House with only token debate like so many other pieces of its legislation.
My colleague from Etobicoke North is a reasonable man. He would not ask the government to reveal any information that would compromise the bargaining position of our country. He is a former diplomat of stature. The member for Etobicoke North is probably far more aware of the intricacies of trilateral negotiations than
March 24, 1992

the minister of whom he seeks answers. Yet he is treated by those opposite with things like: "Don't worry, be happy. We'll tell you about the deal when the time is right".
As negotiations enter the home stretch, the time of that right is now. Having seen the economic havoc in this country in part caused by the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, the Canadian people hardly want to see this government sign another deal without some concrete precautions. The main issue we are talking about today is the integrity of this government, not simply the pros and cons of a North American free trade agreement. Integrity is not something Canadians are used to seeing from the folks across the way. They are more accustomed to seeing a veil of secrecy descend upon all of their schemes until it is too late to have any impact.
If this government was serious about lending some element of integrity to its trade debate, it would lift the veil of secrecy which currently shields Canadians from knowing all they must know about these negotiations.
In the scheme of things what are we to expect from this government? It has made an art form of state secrecy on very important issues. This is clear from an article on March 13 by Eric Beauchesne of Southam News. The author gave an account of how the Tories have cut funding or access to government departments and agencies and their propensity for publicizing valuable but sometimes embarrassing information.
Mr. Beauchesne wrote: "Stifling the flow of potentially harmful political information has become a Progressive Conservative government trademark".
It is unfortunate that the trademark must descend upon this issue of trade. It is an issue of interest to all of our constituents. We realize that our economic future depends on trade and we must ask ourselves how much we are willing to give up for just secure access to markets without acquiring some type of protection against the countervailing actions taken on items such as softwood lumber.
In 1990 Canada imported $1.7 billion worth of goods from Mexico, accounting for merely 1.3 per cent of our imports. The same year we exported approximately $600 million in goods to Mexico, accounting for .4 per cent of our exports.
Supply
In 1990, direct investment in Canada by Mexican firms and individuals accounted for the grand total of $4 million. That is a rather meagre figure in the scheme of things.
These are cursory figures but they say a lot about our relationship with Mexico. I am sure there are ways we can increase our trade with that country if we so desire without having to sign a trilateral free trade deal along with the United States. Why, in a most agonizing recession, does the government insist that our current free trade agreement with the U.S. must be extended to Mexico and changed? For a country that accounts for 1.3 per cent of our imports, the sky will not fall if we ask a few basic questions on the nature of the negotiations.
As a western Canadian, the priority this government has given to trade within North America does not make all that much sense. There is real work to be done in enhancing our relationship with the Asia Pacific where already four of ten residents of the planet live and where a great deal of the consumption and economic growth in the world is taking place.
The notion that economic prosperity and full employment in Canada hinges primarily on free trade with the United States, and perhaps Mexico, is based on a rather outmoded model of international trade. As the developed world lurches toward a diversified and lean approach to economic interrelationships, Canada seems content to stick with its narrow vision of continentalism.
Seeking an enhanced trading relationship with as many strategically important nations as possible remains as much a fundamental component to trade liberalization as the desire to bring down tariffs and non-tariff barriers. The fastest growing market on the face of the earth lies along the Asian rim of the Pacific Ocean. As rapid advances in transportation and communication technology have proven in recent years, one ocean is not a significant geographic barrier in the 1990s.
There are more important reasons, however, why Canada ought to devote more energy and enthusiasm toward building a more rewarding trade relationship with the Asia Pacific.
The Asia Pacific region will be home to approximately 600 million relatively affluent consumers by the turn of the century. The market will be very large and profitable for many Canadian commodities, products and services in addition to natural resources.

March 24, 1992
Supply
The advanced nations of the Asia Pacific are on the cutting edge of technology development and productivity enhancement. A closer and broader relationship with them could result in the fruits of their research and development initiatives and industrial strategies reaching the hands of Canadian firms committed to sustained and comprehensive joint ventures.
Embracing the concept of a broader Asia Pacific-Ca-nada co-operation would begin to improve prospects for diversified economic development and sustained prosperity for about eight million western and northern Canadians. Two-way transfers of technical, education, managerial and professional skills are areas offering particular promise.
A healthy trade relationship with markets in the Asia Pacific region would provide a counterweight to offset the economic and political dominance of the U.S., enhanced by the FTA.
Thousands of people now immigrate to Canada every year from Asia Pacific countries. Many of them are skilled professionals with numerous contacts and an abundance of knowledge pertaining to commercial ventures in their native lands. Many others come to Canada on student visas to attend our universities and colleagues. Many in the Asia Pacific see North America as an exceptional venue for investing capital. An Asia Pacific trade strategy must seek to persuade more ventures of all sizes to focus more attention on direct investment in our country.
Our FTA, as everybody but the government knows, has proven to be a very uneasy commercial accord, to say the least. In the three years since its implementation, it has become clear that Canada under the present agreement will either have to adapt our economic, social and political institutions to reflect those of our more powerful partner, or we can watch our once enviable manufacturing sector disappear. It is hard to see how Canada can achieve a truly global trade profile within a parochial trade bloc.
One of Canada's foremost economists, Sylvia Ostry, addressed the sorry state of Canada's competitiveness in the following way: "Pursuing a purely North American strategy cannot provide a safe haven".
Today, western Canadians, and I think all Canadians, have grown weary of a Europe-centric and a U.S.-centric approach to developing trade priorities. While our
neighbour to the south has been a valued and respected commercial partner throughout our history, our neighbours across the Pacific Ocean have redefined international economic order of the future.
Last year 80 per cent of Canada's entire export trade with this region involved the four western provinces. By comparison, the western provinces only accounted for 22 per cent of Canada's exports to the United States. Our proximity in the west to Pacific ports would be ideal for manufacturing interests and high technology industries which wish to establish factories to produce goods for export to Asia.
Japan has become Canada's second largest trading partner with a total export trade value of over $8 billion in 1990, second only to the United States. Trade officials expect Japan to become British Columbia's top trade partner this year.
As well, 54 per cent of all immigrants from Asia Pacific who come to Canada settle in the four western provinces. Many of them, as I have said, are highly energetic entrepreneurial people who can do so much to help us increase our trade with the countries they formerly lived in.
Finally, large firms in the Asia Pacific see Canada as a great venue for investing capital and purchasing securities. Yet generally speaking Canadian firms still do not seem to be aggressive enough in seeking out those sources of capital and trade. This situation persists despite the fact that $4.1 billion in direct investment came to Canada from Hong Kong alone in 1990.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to make some comments on the NAFTA agreement.
Negotiations toward a North American free trade agreement are one component of the government's over-all economic and trade strategy aimed at enhancing Canada's future growth and competitiveness. The negotiations are seeking to create a North American market, free of tariffs and non-tariff barriers. The agreement would permit the free flow of goods, services and investments among the three countries. It would provide for the protection of intellectual property rights and it would establish a fair and expeditious dispute settlement mechanism. It would create a market of 360 million people, larger than the 12 countries of the European Community.
This is an ambitious undertaking. The agreement is being negotiated at a timely moment. The nations of the world are struggling to complete multilateral negotiations aimed at creating a more level playing field for exporters. As a trade dependent country, Canada will benefit from more open markets globally. While Canada currently ranks eighth in the world in the export of goods, and twelfth in the exported services, our future prosperity depends on building upon this successful track record.
This has nothing to do with playgrounds. Three million jobs in Canada are dependent on exports and are on the line. The export community has underlined the importance of a more focused approach to supporting Canadian businesses in its pursuit to global market opportunities.

March 24, 1992
Supply
The NAFTA negotiations constitute but one step in this direction. To be competitive in the world, our industry must successfully compete in North America. The North American agreement would benefit the wide range of export-oriented Canadian goods, producers and service providers.
I would like to focus my remarks on how the NAFTA will especially help smaller and medium-sized Canadian companies. With a growth population and economic reforms that have opened up its economy, Mexico is becoming North America's fastest-growing market. The country's annual economic growth exceeded 4 per cent in 1991 and imports are increasing by more than 30 per cent annually.
This offers immediate markets for Canadian suppliers of competitive products and services that are urgently needed for Mexico's modernization and diversification. Its potential as a key market is undeniable and the NAFTA will secure the access of this growing market to Canadian exporters.
The success of the recent Canadian Expo '92 in Monterrey, Mexico underscored that a wide range of Canadian firms are already focusing on opportunities created by the launch of the North American negotiations.
More than 200 firms from across Canada representing 11 industrial sectors participated in Canada's largest trade promotion ever held in Latin America. Judging from the results, participation in that show was well worth the effort. There was close to $3 million in on-site sales and an additional $80 million expected over the next 12 to 18 months.
For other small to medium-sized Canadian firms, the NAFTA will provide important opportunities to improve their competitive positions in the more medium term. We strongly believe an agreement will encourage small and medium-sized firms to form the strategic alliances in North America that can give them the needed edge to meet and beat tough offshore competition.
Japanese business success shows how a company should use the best of the resources available to it, whether those resources be domestic or foreign. A North
American free trade agreement will permit companies in all three countries to do just that. They will put into action the best of what each country has to offer.
Of course, many smaller Canadian firms have yet to discover Mexico as a market. Just as the free trade agreement encouraged some Canadian firms to think about exports to the United States, for the first time the prospect of a NAFTA has already stimulated unprecedented levels of interest on the part of Canadian firms in the dynamic markets of Latin America.
For the smaller firms focusing on the U.S.A. market, the NAFTA will add to the gains of the FTA. We will not allow the hard-fought deals made in the FTA to be reopened nor accept reductions in benefits that accrue to Canada under this agreement. But if during the NAFTA negotiations we see possibilities for improving the provisions of the FTA in ways that can benefit Canada, then we will do so.
We believe improvements may be possible with respect to such practical matters as more straightforward rules of origin and greater customs co-operation. This is not necessarily the stuff of headlines but it represents real improvements on day-to-day operations of businesses exporting within North America. These are the kinds of improvements that will benefit most small Canadian companies.
In the controversy generated around initiatives such as this one, the main purpose of our efforts sometimes becomes obscure or forgotten. It is plainly stated to reduce obstacles to trade. There is nothing base about this idea especially to a small and dynamic trade-dependent country.
Canadian negotiators will focus on dismantling Mexico's trade barriers which have hampered the efforts of Canadian exporters to compete for a slice of the Mexican market of 85 million people. They will focus on a trilateral deal which will preclude a bilateral U.S.-Mexi-co trade deal that would have created preferential access for the U.S. and stacked the deck against Canadian businesses and our economy. They will ensure that Canadian manufacturers have access to cost-efficient inputs and that Canadian exporters can forge the strategic alliances in North America needed to improve their competitiveness.
March 24, 1992

As our export statistics indicate, even small and medium-sized Canadian firms have already shown they have the know-how and ability to make important inroads in international markets. NAFTA will be another important tool to ensure that these firms have a freer environment to capitalize on.
In summary, this debate is not about playgrounds. It is real to the three million Canadians who depend on exports for their livelihood. It is real to the many small and medium-sized Canadian companies which are striving to make further inroads into international markets for the benefit of Canadians who depend on their success.

"This is as true for NAFTA as it is with the Uruguay round of the GATT". Is this the close consultation that Mr. Weekes meant, that he would negotiate through the Toronto Star? This is quite a speech. It just flies in the face as to what really has happened in the NAFTA negotiations.
I would ask the member to comment on the speech of John Weekes, our chief negotiator.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate having the opportunity to speak on this opposition motion put forward by my colleague from Etobicoke North.
I would like to repeat it for those listening this afternoon:

March 24, 1992
Supply
That this House condemn the Government for its failure to be
completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and
objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
The central issue in public life today is trust because of the experience with the last free trade agreement. When I say experience I mean the results that have occurred in our economy, the job losses, the rapid deterioration of our manufacturing base in southern Ontario, the incidents we have had in terms of softwood lumber, the Honda dispute in Alliston, and on and on it goes.
There is the natural feeling that any further negotiation would leave us as a nation more exposed in any kind of a free trade agreement. How could it possibly be a benefit to Canada? How could it possibly be a benefit to those whose lives depend upon exports not only to the United States, but also to the rest of the world?
We are forgetting some of the things that have happened as a result of this free trade agreement in relation to manufacturing, not only the shrinking of the economy but also the way head offices in the United States have basically shut down their manufacturing in Canada. They have basically turned their Canadian operations into nothing more than distribution centres or marketing and sales operations.
There are so many of these incidents happening across the country that we now naturally get the feeling that there is even a greater danger as we continue with a similar trading relationship with Mexico. It is absolutely essential, if we are going to begin any kind of a rebuild on trust in any kind of a trade negotiation, that these discussions be totally open. There should not be any action that looks like we are doing this behind closed doors.
Most of us in this House know that one of the things that Canadians do not like is the fact that we seem to be tying our trade destiny to the United States.
One of the greatest assets that we have in this country is the fact that we are a multicultural nation. Over the last 20 years this country has spent millions and millions of dollars encouraging people to retain their cultural
heritage and their language. We have people who have come to this country from all over the world.
When we first started on multiculturalism back in 1971, there was an awful lot of criticism as to why we would be spending taxpayers' money and encouraging people to retain and promote their cultural heritage.
Here we are in the 1990s and the greatest trading asset that we have in this country is the fact that we have people from every part of the world, Canadian citizens, who have retained their cultural heritage and language because of this government's policies. It means they can now go to any country in the world. We do not need to have our trade policy linked and welded to the United States. Naturally we are going to continue to enjoy that great trading relationship, but we should make sure we develop some counterweights.
My colleague from Etobicoke North wrote a paper a few months ago. He suggested it was essential we build counterweights in this country to the United States.
I happen to think one of the counterweights, in terms of trade, is the fact that because of our multicultural fabric, we can send people all over the world.
About five years ago I had the opportunity to work for an auto parts manufacturer, Magna International. We had an opportunity to go to Tokyo to make a presentation to the Toyota operation. We made sure we brought a couple of young Japanese Canadians with us on that trip who were fluent in Japanese and understood the culture. These Japanese Canadians played such an incredibly productive role in our negotiations that we were able to bring back an order that was close to $50 million on our first visit.
That order created a lot of jobs in our factory here in Canada and I dare say it was because we brought Canadians of Japanese origin to that table, who had the facility of language and were so comfortable with the culture.
We can do that in every region of the world. We have had many people go to different parts of the world in the last few years from this House. We have always been able to have very special connections because there has either been someone in our constituency who was from the particular region we were visiting, or they had friends or family there. We have never really fully exploited the

March 24, 1992

linkage of language and culture that we have encouraged, promoted and built in this country over the last 20 years.
I think the government should not be so possessed and preoccupied in terms of the North American scene. It should start putting an added thrust in other parts of the world and use our assets. The owners of small and medium sized businesses need the support and assistance of government to re-establish those linkages. The mere fact they have that facility of language and culture would access us to those markets in very short order. That would allow us to have the counterweight in our trading policy that would give us a much stronger position when we are trading with the Americans.
The other counterweight when it comes to the United States is the fact we have the most fresh water of any nation in the world. It is no secret to anyone in North America that eventually the Americans are going to need our water.
We should make absolutely sure in whatever discussions go on here that water is not part of any trade deal in any way, shape, or form.
I think we would be doing a tremendous disservice to Canadians if we were cloudy on that particular issue.
I support the member for Etobicoke North's motion. There is such a low level of trust in any kind of trade negotiations going on in this country right now, that the government is going to have to bend over backward to rebuild that trust.

March 24, 1992

I want to go back to the point the member made regarding the royal commission on the economy. My colleague from Willowdale reminded me they did call for adjustments. In other words, you did this free trade deal and you left absolutely no room for any kind of economic adjustments. The Royal Commission on the Economy agreed to free trade, but said there must absolutely be adjustments. He just sort of left those out and that is a key point.
I want to go back to Mr. Trudeau. He was not anti-American as some people try to pretend in their language and newspapers. Mr. Trudeau constantly favoured a global trading position for this country so we were not totally dependent on our American friends to the south. To this day when you travel in Europe, the Middle East-I cannot speak for South America-or some parts of Africa and speak to businessmen there, they have an image of this country and it is Trudeau. It is a good one and they saw him as a positive force on trade. To this day, we owe the former Prime Minister a great deal of debt and gratitude for his trading skills.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is rather embarrassing to see the Tories squabbling. Some are in favour of a referendum and others are opposed to the idea. However, I must say the minister has done a good job, and we support him. We wish him the best of luck with the constitutional proposals.

It would help our national unity if we had an economy that was vibrant and strong, instead of losing jobs overnight to the United States.
I would like to look at just one sector of our economy that has lost badly in the three years under free trade. It is not just because of free trade, but because of a whole raft of Tory economic policies which tilted the playing field in favour of the Americans, such as our high interest rates policies, our high dollar policies, our high tax policies and our GST. The NDP programs in Ontario are threatening to create labour strife and drive more and more jobs out of province. A previous government did not suggest or enact in Ontario the programs that are now being advocated.
Let us get back to the issue of this government's program for free trade and what it has done to our auto sector. In the three years since free trade, Canada has lost 127,213 automotive jobs in assembly and auto parts manufacturing. That is, 21 per cent of all the jobs in that industry in three years have disappeared.
Now the Tories will tell us some of those jobs have been lost in the United States as well. Of course they have. They have not lost 21 per cent of their automotive jobs, they have lost only 9 per cent of them. So you cannot blame that on the recession. The fact is we are losing jobs more quickly than they are.
They now have an opportunity with the North American free trade agreement to perhaps make some changes to the way in which we trade in automobiles. I hope they will make these changes.
I suggest they consider a North American content rule. Presently we have a free trade agreement in Canada which says you can trade free trade in automotives if you have a 50 per cent North American content. You saw what happened in the Honda case. The Americans claimed they just did not quite meet the 50 per cent level, therefore the Americans could impose taxes on cars made in Ontario and shipped to the United States.
I want this House to reconsider this 50 per cent North American content rule. Are we going to be the only free traders in the world in automotives or not? I wish we had genuine free trade in many things in this world and a level playing field but the reality is, we do not. When you look at foreign penetration of the European Community, they are now arguing among themselves whether by the year 2000 they will allow non-European automobiles into their market to the tune of 15 per cent or 17 per cent. That is the debate. In Japan, foreign automobile makers have 3 per cent of the market. What do we have in Canada? It is 37 per cent. Should we be the only free traders in a world where our competition is not free trading? This is one of the issues we have to face. Free trade may be good for consumers. It may be the right thing to do, but it is not what our competitors do. So let us not be naive.
There are ways in which we can reduce this 37 per cent penetration by foreigners of our automobile markets in North America. I really think in the interests of jobs that we have to consider some of those measures.
March 24, 1992

People will say that if we do not have unbridled competition we are going to suffer in terms of our competitiveness because we will not be as productive and we will not have the quality. We can overcome those objections by working closely with our auto manufacturers to ensure that they are world class.
I am impressed that under the threat of Japanese competition in the last few years we have increased our productivity and our quality to a point where North American vehicles are good vehicles. Let us start to get those jobs back and continue the progress we have made in terms of quality and productivity.
Are we going to have Canadian content rules, not just greater North American content rules but Canadian content rules in a North American free trade zone? If we do not, we will find ourselves in the precise position we are in today where under the free trade agreement with the United States the big three can pull their production out of Canada. They do not have to buy any Canadian parts. After the year 1998 when all the tariffs are phased out they can ship duty-free into Canada without having one Canadian job here. That is the way the present trade regime works.
In other words, the free trade agreement wiped out the auto pact. Under the auto pact, in return for participating in Canada's market we insisted that they created a certain number of jobs here. For every car brought into Canada duty free one car had to be produced in Canada. A certain degree of protectionism was offered in return for jobs.
That is what we are doing today as well under the entire concept of a North American free trade agreement. There was never any concept that we would allow unlimited free trade on a global basis. We were contemplating that we would have a common tariff against foreign automobiles. We were not going to let the foreigners come in without any duties. Therefore, we have said as a North American group that we are not in favour of free trade. We are in favour of erecting some type of barriers against foreign penetration.
Let us not pretend that we are being globalized and involved in free trade when we say as a group that we are going to erect common barriers. We have established what game we are in. It is protectionism in return for
Supply
jobs. Now let us make sure we get our fair share of jobs. That is why a common North American barrier against foreign penetration is one way of doing it. Having Canadian content is a way to ensure that we will have our fair share of auto jobs here in Canada.
I suggest that we go back to restoring what we had under the auto pact, those safeguards for Canadian jobs. We do not want to give up all auto jobs here in Canada. In return for other North American partners shipping into Canada duty free, let us make sure that they establish a certain number of jobs in Canada. Why is this important? It is because we do not have a totally level playing field right now.
The big three-GM, Chrysler and Ford-are not Canadian companies. They are located in the United States. They are subject to the pressures of the U.S. government. They are subject to pressures of unions which are far bigger. When it comes to closing plants it is highly probable that we do not have the leverage the United States does in making sure that we keep our fair share of jobs.
Let us look at what has happened in the last three years. We have lost auto jobs at two and a third times the rate the Americans have. This is why when we approach these discussions there is no sector more important than the automotive sector. I want to make sure that this government is realistic in terms of world standards and in terms of standing up for Canadians and Canadian auto workers.

The member is talking about this notion of global competitiveness and linking everything difficult that is happening in our country to this ogre of the trade treaty. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is no doubt that we are in a global economy. Let us not get trapped into saying that a global economy means that there are not barriers being erected.
I have to comment first of all on what the hon. member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore said. He is usually a very intelligent, a very erudite person, an author, but he has bought into the Tory propaganda that the free trade agreement did not wipe out the auto pact.
The auto pact was not abolished by the free trade agreement. It was left there, but the means of enforcing the auto pact were taken away. Those means were the
tariffs which said that duties had to be paid if one car was not produced in Canada for every car brought in. We wiped out those duties. They will be totally phased out by 1998. They did not eliminate the auto pact in the free trade agreement. They just took away the means of enforcing it, which is the same as wiping it out. Let us not be naive. That is what this government has done.
This member said that I was in favour of free trade. Yes, I am in favour of free trade, but is he saying that in the NAFTA agreement they are not going to erect a common barrier against European, Japanese and Korean vehicles coming into North America? Of course they are. The European community erects common barriers against North American and Japanese cars.
This is unfortunately the way of the world. We are in a world that is not engaged in globalized free trade. We are engaged in a world of trading blocs. Let us make sure, first, that our trading bloc gets its fair share of automotive jobs, automotive production. Second, let us make sure that Canada within our own trading bloc has its fair share.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to join in this debate today. I would like to make a few remarks off the top about some of the tenor of the debate so far today.
There has been an awful lot of fear-mongering in this Chamber. As we listened to what some of the members in the opposition were saying, a lot of us reflected back to a debate we heard some three and a half years ago during the free trade agreement negotiations with the United States. I am sure we all remember that.
I vividly remember during the last election campaign going around and people saying to me: "Well, the Liberal candidate was here a little while ago and said we were going to lose our social programs when we have free trade with the Americans". Other people told me: "We have been told we are going to lose medicare once we have free trade with the Americans". Then it was water. They said that we were going to lose control of our own natural resources including water, that water was going to be shipped wholesale from Canada to the United States if we entered into this free trade agreement.
March 24, 1992

It went beyond that. People were being told during the election campaign that free trade meant Canada would lose its infrastructure, that our whole social infrastructure would be lost. Not only that. They were told that our environmental standards would be eroded. That was a big one.
I remember the NDP television commercials with Ed Broadbent or some older guy walking beside a pond with a child. A clear message was being sent to Canadians night after night that if we signed a free trade agreement our environmental standards would go out the window.
All those free trade agreement bogymen are being dragged back into this Chamber once again in a desperate attempt by opposition people to make Canadians believe what they rightfully and forcefully rejected in 1988. That is all that has been going on here today, and I think Canadians deserve a better level of debate than that.
Canadians have been watching this debate. I am sure many of them are confused and a little frustrated by some of the things being said in this Chamber. People are being confused by the black and white nature of the arguments being put forward. Most Canadians know better. They know that the arguments are not all black and they are not all white. There are shades of grey which really dictate it. There are good things about NAFTA. There are things that are not going to be good about NAFTA. It is the role of the Canadian government now to negotiate strongly and forcefully to get the best deal possible for Canada.
I am sure a lot of Canadians listening to the debate today are a little ticked off as well by the politics of fear which are being brought into this debate. It is not logic, not common sense, not a dispassionate look at what is good and bad for Canada, but just a whole bunch of emotional rhetoric designed to frighten people. That is not what Canadians deserve.
The motion we are talking about today reads:
That the House condemn the government for its failure to be completely open with Canadians about its principal goals and objectives in the current North American free trade negotiations.
Flow did we get this particular motion today? It is typical of what goes on in Ottawa. A lot of people got up
Supply
this morning, read the headlines in the newspaper and turned it into a motion in the House of Commons.
On Sunday The Ottawa Citizen ran the second in a series of articles called "The Human Cost of Free Trade". The front page of The Ottawa Citizen had a picture of an impoverished Mexican peasant. Inside there was no reference at all to any of the particulars of the free trade agreement proposals. It was just simply how bad life was in Mexico. We all feel for Mexican peasants. We all want to make their life better. There is a body of thought that says helping the Mexicans improve their economy not only helps the Mexican peasants; it helps Canadians as well.
Then this morning we had this story "Leaked document reveals massive three-way trade plan" splattered all over the front of The Toronto Star. I saw my "Star" this morning and I was pretty interested in the story. It looked like the second coming. I started reading it and thought: "Surely I am going to have some kind of fair and balanced story".
Who leaked the document? What does the document say? What is the government response? What is the context that this happened in?
The story was written by Linda Diebel. Linda Diebel is a pretty good reporter so I expected a fair and balanced story. What do I find? I find a plant, a Ralph Nader plant, in The Toronto Star. They just swallowed it. They took it all, hook, line and sinker. They had no verification whatsoever.
We have quoted in this story the Citizen Tradewatch Campaign, which is a Ralph Nader established organization. We have the Sierra Club quoted in here. It is an American organization being quoted on the agreement.
We have Public Citizen, which is part of the Consumer Advocate Network of Ralph Nader. We have a lot of people quoted in this story. None of them are Canadian. Nobody in the government was given an opportunity to put this into context. It is a totally incredible, one-sided story.
Therefore I would like to read into the record a couple of comments which were made two and a half hours ago just outside this Chamber. They are contained in a story which ran on the Canadian Press wire about an hour ago.

March 24, 1992
Supply
I will quote verbatim a couple of paragraphs: "'A leaked version of the proposed three-way trade agreement among Canada, the United States and Mexico is simply a preliminary document and does not mean Canada has given anything away', according to International Trade Minister Michael Wilson". If somebody should know, he ought to know.
'"It is a draft text', says the minister. 'The document is a very preliminary document'." The minister adds that just because they put forward the couple of proposals contained in that article, it does not mean that Canada is accepting them. In fact, the minister has said that, for example, the proposal on telecommunications that the Americans put forward has been rejected by Canada. We are not buying it.
This particular agreement that is in The Toronto Star and printed as if it is from the Bible is nothing but a working draft negotiating text. End of story. It does not matter. Nothing in this text matters. The Americans put forward their best case of what they wanted from Canada, it does not matter. We are negotiating a deal. We can reject it.
Canadians are watching this debate based on the premise that this planted story by a left wing, activist group from the United States and bought hook, line and sinker by The Toronto Star is fact. We are here tying up the Chamber of the House of Commons debating something which is not based on fact. It is not based in fact. It is not balanced and it is not reasoned journalism. I think it is an insult to a lot of people to put up with this.
I would like to address the NDP claim in this House that somehow the federal government has been trying to muzzle members of Parliament or conceal the facts of NAFTA while U.S. and Mexican parliamentarians have had full access. That is the way the argument has been developed in the Chamber.
Let us review the facts. The Government of Canada has offered a briefing to members of this House to review not a leaked draft text, but the working text that Canada is now proposing at NAFTA.
Members of this House from the government side and the opposition side have the opportunity of being fully briefed, of having it done after signing an agreement that says that the contents will be kept confidential.
That has been put forward as a position that is diametrically opposed to that which the American and Mexican parliamentarians have been offered. I would like to review it.
What have American legislators been offered by their government in terms of having a look at this agreement? The American government is essentially sustaining the same kinds of criticisms that the Canadian government is right now, that the United States is giving confidential briefings to legislators in the United States but they are classified briefings.
The only people being given confidential briefings are members of Congress and their staffers, and private sector trade advisory members and their staffers. Those briefings are only being given to the Americans after a full security background check has been made into those people who will be at the briefing. It is just the same as that being offered here in Canada. But Canadian parliamentarians who are being offered briefings by the government do not have to go through a security check. They just have to agree that what they see will be confidential.
The NDP in this House has made much of saying Mexican senators have been getting briefings on roughly what is in the free trade negotiating documents. What the Mexican senators have been offered is not a confidential briefing. No confidential briefings whatsoever have been offered any members of the Mexican opposition.
I think what the Government of Canada has been offering in this House has been much more than either the Americans or the Mexicans have been offering to our counterparts in those legislatures.
That is myth number one which we have to address here.
Myth number two is that Canadians in general, not just Canadian legislators, have not been informed adequately about has been going on here, about what the heck the government has been doing in terms of negotiating some kind of a free trade agreement with the Americans and the Mexicans.
It is interesting to note that the government has had more than 48 meetings on the North American free trade proposed agreement since negotiations were launched.
March 24, 1992

The minister responsible for international trade has personally delivered more than a dozen speeches from Fredericton to Vancouver. In each speech-and I have read them-he details a few more elements of the free trade agreement. If you look at those speeches as a body of material, they give an incredible insight into what the Government of Canada is trying to achieve through these agreements.
The minister has personally written almost 400 letters to Canadians in response to inquiries on the agreement. The chief negotiator, Mr. Weekes, has given 26 speeches to groups of Canadians on the free trade agreement. There have been more than 2,800 copies of Situation Report distributed to Canadians who have made inquiries about the NAFTA. There have been 10 background briefings to the press since September.
The minister has appeared before the standing committee of the House of Commons seven times to answer any questions relating to the free trade agreement.
The minister himself has given a number of speeches from one end of the country to the other. Let me give members a glimpse: the Financial Post Conference on North American Free Trade in Montreal, Council of the Americas and the Canadian Manufacturers' Association in Toronto, the Central Canada Broadcasters' Association in Toronto, the MacDonald-Cartier Club in Calgary, Canadian-American Committee in Toronto, and the list goes on.
From one end of the country to the other the minister has been there. He has been before the House of Commons committee. There has been no attempt to avoid giving information on free trade.
I submit that the motion that the government has some hidden agenda in terms of the free trade agreement with North America is absolutely political bunk and rhetoric.
There are a couple of words I would like to say on the agreement itself.
Why are we doing this? What are Canada's objectives? Why are we even sitting at the table with the Americans and Mexicans trying to construct a free trade agreement?
Supply
The first and most important thing for Canadians, Canadian business people, Canadian entrepreneurs, is the fact that there are 80 million people in Mexico and right now the Mexicans have a lot of barriers to our companies reaching that market of 80 million people. Obviously it would be to our benefit if we could reduce some of those barriers, if we could bring them down and increase the accessibility.
Second, we need to have better access to the United States market. Much has been made today in the House about some of the problems that have come up, whether it has been a ruling on the content of Honda cars, softwood lumber, pork disputes, et cetera.
Some of the hon. members who have raised those things as examples of free trade not really helping us because we still have problems in part are right. We still do have problems. The Americans are very protectionist right now. The Americans want to protect their economy because they are in some of the same dire straits that we are in. They have a recession and an election coming up. They are using trade laws as a way of attacking some of those that are being successful in getting their products into the American market, including Canadians.
The free trade agreement, as we have negotiated it, helps but it does not do everything that is possible. As we sit down with the Americans and the Mexicans now and look once again at free trade, the way it works, the irritants, and so on, if we can possibly make that deal better and remove some of the irritants and strengthen Canada's position, then why would we not do it?
That is the second objective that Canada could have under these negotiations.
Third, we want to make the investment climate better in Canada. There is nothing whatsoever wrong with foreign investment in this country. We welcome foreign investment. It has always built Canada. Other countries are happy when entrepreneurial Canadians go to their countries and invest in their infrastructure; we should be just as happy here.
Those are the three things I would like people to remember about objectives: gain access to a market of 80 million people; tiy and improve the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement; and make Canada a more attractive place for investment.

March 24, 1992
Supply
Why negotiate a deal with Mexico? Right now it is becoming a very dynamic economy. The Mexicans do not want to be a Third World country, they want to be a first world country. It appears that with the kind of aggression it has right now, it is going to make it. As it improves its economy, as it increases the wealth in that economy, individual Mexicans are going to prosper. They are going to have more money to spend, and that is only good for us in Canada because we want to access that market.
It is clear now that Canada can really play a major role in these trade negotiations by reshaping the way the whole western hemisphere trading patterns are taking place.
Finally, globalization: it is here to stay. We cannot hold it back. It does not matter how much little Canada, with its little market of 26 million people wants to protect our own industries, we cannot do it any more. We cannot buck a trend that the whole world is moving toward. So we have to be at the table with the Americans and the Mexicans. It would be ridiculous for us to walk away. We have to be there to protect our own interests.
A question that comes from a lot of people is: "Okay, we understand that; you've got to be at the table; it would be irresponsible to take a hike, but how can we possibly compete with workers in a country where wages are so incredibly low?" I think that is a really valid question and we have to come up with a reasonable answer or else we risk losing the support of a lot of people in these negotiations.
I would say to those people who worry about that, the answer is that on average about 12 to 15 per cent of the cost of a product is accounted for by wages. It is a fairly low percentage. Less than 2 per cent of the goods that Canada buys abroad come from Mexico. So we are not looking at a very great threat here. It is a really reasonable element of the total cost of producing something that is sent to Canada.
It is also interesting to note that the biggest trading countries in the world are not low wage countries. The biggest trading countries are countries like Canada, the United States, Germany, and Japan. These are countries that have high wages now and yet they still have been able to become the great trading countries of the world. It is not the low wage countries that have been able to
take over world trading patterns. They have not been able to do it. For the critics to stand now and say that just because they have low wages in Mexico means they are going to become large trading countries does not follow. We have no experience like that.
I would like to conclude by saying that I do not think Canadians have anything to fear from trade negotiations with any country. We have an environment where we have well-educated workers, we have an excellent infrastructure, we have some of the strongest and largest financial institutions in the whole world. We have a lot in this country that puts us into a very favoured position in terms of trading with anybody in the world.
We cannot hold back world trends. We cannot stand there with our hand up to history, saying: "Stop, Canada wants off here, Canada doesn't want to be part of a globalization of trade". You cannot do it. We must press forward and the government is on the right track. If we cannot get a good deal for Canada we will not take a deal.

Sources familiar with the talks warn that the U.S. side-which is looking over its shoulder at a hawkish Congress-is putting forward proposals that would protect politically powerful regional U.S. industries. The Americans are out to put the boots to us," complains Stephen Beatty, executive director of the Canadian Apparel Manufacturers' Institute.

speechtext: Stephen Beatty? Where have I heard that name?

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81 -NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE NEGOTIATIONS
speechtext:
Many observers of NAFTA say what little gains Canada made in the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement will most certainly be lost under what is being negotiated at NAFTA.
As the hon. member for Halton-Peel well knows, Canada is already under pressure from the U.S. regarding softwood lumber and the Honda dispute. Now I hear the alarm bells starting to sound in the textile industry. In my riding of Hamilton West we have a textile manufacturer which employs 700 to 800 individuals and they are concerned.
March 24, 1992

Let me give the member an example. Presently, Canadian clothing manufacturers can sell a limited amount of clothing containing foreign fabrics to stores on Fifth Avenue in New York. They cannot sell to the U.S. in bulk clothing that has foreign components. This is why the U.S. has ruled against Honda Civics which is not right because the manufacturing takes place in Canada.
Under the NAFTA, the U.S. is considering that every single fibre resulting in the end product of clothing be North American. They are insisting that the yarn, the cloth and clothing be all North American, no foreign components allowed at all.

This is the specific question that the member is looking for because he says it is all a bunch of hyperbole and emotional rhetoric, et cetera. These are concerns of our industries in our ridings. The best protection that all of our industries and those men and women in our ridings who work in the industries which are threatened from time to time can have is if Canada has trading agreements, whether it is at the
Supply
GATT or whether it is with NAFTA or whether it is under FTA, specific trading agreements which have built into them specific dispute settlement mechanisms.
Obviously, the Americans are going to try and get as much as they want out of this deal. I hope that our Canadian negotiators are ruthless and try to get as much as possible out of the deal for Canada. Government Orders
failure of the Tory government to keep interest rates and the dollar down. That is the real problem. It created a terrible recession in this country, and that is why we are going to suffer the consequences for the next 10 years. subtopic: EDUCATION
EDUCATION
speechtext:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should
establish a national task force to discuss national standards of
education.
He said: Mr. Speaker, the motion I have put before the House and which I am asking the House to support calls for the federal government to establish a task force to discuss national education standards.
The motion arises from extensive research that has convinced me that education is directly linked to competitiveness. Canada's education system needs to be overhauled to make us better able to compete in a changing world economy.
The key to competitiveness is productivity. The productivity of a nation is closely linked to the literacy levels of its citizens. This is especially true today.
The acceleration of technology and the globalization of trade is changing the workplace and placing increasing demand on the work force.
Current skills are devalued and new ones are created at an alarming rate, but Canada's education system is not keeping up with the demand. A high percentage of our work force is illiterate to some degree and unable to cope with new technology.
Tomorrow's workers are graduating from education programs that no longer equip them with the skills required for meaningful employment. The secret of improved productivity is to improve the skill of the average Canadian.
In the 21st century, natural resources, capital and technology will move around the world. A nation's strategic asset will be the skills of its work force. Literacy and human resource development are therefore central
to Canada's economic development, and our competitive future as well.
We need to ensure that Canadians are able to cope with the challenges of a changing workplace. One of the most important ways we can do that is to establish national education standards.
Several broad trends are serving to strengthen the ties between literacy levels and productivity. For example, in an advanced economy, there is steady growth and jobs requiring reading and communications skills. Economic structures are changing with the fast growth of high technology and the relative decline of natural resources and traditional manufacturing.
As you know, Canada specializes in resource related goods. In the 1950s and 1960s, this gave countries an edge in the world market. Today, however, there is a great emphasis on high-tech manufactured goods. Resource commodities are being replaced by information and knowledge-intensive goods.
In this new knowledge-based world, trading advantage depends more on acquired knowledge and skills than on a wealth of natural resources. Canadians are losing ground to industrial competitors who are better than they are at manufacturing, inventing, designing and marketing.
Economic structuring means that the nature of jobs is changing. Firms are reorganizing in order to cope with the increasing international competition and market diversification. In both the manufacturing and service sectors of the economy, these trends imply greater demand for information and communications skills, as well as analytical abilities. Companies, for example, are trying to reorder production so they can respond more quickly and with greater flexibility to market shifts. The changes are placing increasing demand on workers to be able to handle varied tasks, respond to unexpected situations, communicate with other workers and management and train more extensively in the use of special technologies.
Jobs with low literacy skill demands are disappearing. In a report entitled "Workforce Literacy: An Economic Challenge for Canada", the Hudson Institute estimates the fastest growing occupation will demand math skills, verbal and communication skills and management abilities. Jobs in blue collar areas, assembly work in most primary industries will be much harder to find. In
March 24, 1992

addition, Canadians will have to be able to learn new skills throughout their working lives to keep up with continual technological change.
According to the Hudson Institute, workers' skills and specialized knowledge become obsolete in about three to five years. Just a decade ago, skills stayed current for seven to 14 years.
The Department of Employment and Immigration predicts that many low-skilled jobs will simply disappear. High school dropouts could comer 46.7 per cent of the job market in 1986. Between 1989 and the year 2000, only 37 per cent of new jobs will be offered to those with less than grade 12 education.
Globalization of the economy also affects productivity. Traditionally, Canadians have lived in a relatively insulated environment created by a history of market production. The current trend toward trade revitalization is placing increasing pressure on Canadian workers.
lake, for example, the free trade agreement. It was designed to enhance wealth through productivity. Inevitably, low productivity jobs will be replaced with those demanding proficiency in basic skills. Yet, even as the demands for literacy and basic skills are increasing, the supply is diminishing.
We are facing a demographic revolution that is depleting the labour market. The availability of workers will decline in the decades ahead. Two-thirds who will be in the work force in the year 2005 are already in the work force today, according to the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre. If this is true, companies can expect tight labour markets. Employment and Immigration figures indicate that in 1986 51 per cent of the population was between the ages of 15 and 34. By 2001, that figure will drop to 40 per cent. However, the percentage of those between the ages of 35 and 54 will increase to almost 50 per cent by the year 2001 compared to 38 per cent in 1986.
Given the declining birth rate, employers will be less able to rely on new young graduates to meet their skill requirements. Until recently, employers have counted on educated young people to bring up-to-date specialized skills to the work force. The pool of highly qualified and highly skilled youth is expected to decline by nearly 25 per cent over the next 10 years.
Private Members' Business
Along with the need to provide quality education in schools and universities, it is obvious there is also a need to further educate the existing labour force.
In many ways, the Canadian education system is superior among countries with advanced economies. Proportionately, only Denmark and Norway spend more public funds on education than Canada. According to the 1991 World Competitiveness Report, the Canadian government spent $1,350 per capita on education compared to economic contenders such as Germany and Japan which spent $820 and $1,080 per capita respectively.
Traditionally, Canada is also committed to accessibility and fairness in education. Only the United States has a higher percentage of youths between the ages of 20 and 24 enrolled in colleges and universities. However, there seems to be a huge gap between input and output. Canada has the lowest productivity growth of the G-7 countries and a miserable score in key factors of international competitiveness.
In a 1991 survey of 23 countries conducted by the World Economic Forum, Canada ranked poorly in many criteria used to determine competitiveness. The forum looked at factors such as growth of exports, spending on research and development and quantity of skilled labour force. Canada ranked 20th in categories such as export of manufactured products and new business generation and ranked 15th in the availability of skilled labour.
International comparisons generally show we are investing enough to remain competitive as long as the skills our students learn are relevant and applied well. Despite high participation rates and high levels of funding, some of the results of our educational systems have been disappointing. The shortfall is most evident in areas such as literacy and numeracy skills and vocational training.
Nearly 40 per cent of adult Canadians have difficulty reading, writing and doing basic maths tasks, according to a survey of literacy skills used in daily activities. The survey was conducted by Statistics Canada in 1989 on behalf of the National Literacy Secretariat. This study pointed out that literacy is not a problem affecting small, marginal sections of the population. It is a central issue determining the competence of the work force. Estimates vary widely, but it is conceivable that about

March 24, 1992
Private Members' Business
one-third of workers could do their job better if they were able to use basic reading and writing skills better.
The problem of literacy extends beyond a lack of basic skills. Literacy is a dynamic concept related to the evolving needs of the work force. As the demands of most rewarding jobs rise, the definition of functional illiteracy expands. The literacy survey focused on the ability of people to use their information processing skills. The study suggests the largest problem is with those who can read very simple messages, but are not able to apply these skills to complete complex tasks. Companies are using increasingly complex equipment. Instead of taking verbal instructions from a supervisor, workers now need to read, question and respond to printed instructions from a computer. A wide variety of communication needs constantly emerge in business and can also be classified as literacy related. These may include courses offered in the work place on blueprint reading and business writing.
Employee illiteracy has had quite an impact on Canadian business. In a 1990 study conducted by the Conference Board of Canada, 70 per cent of surveyed companies identified a significant problem with illiteracy. The major challenge facing employers was adjusting to rapid market change. Training and retraining become extremely difficult if employees lack the skills needed to absorb and analyse material.
The study also found that illiteracy hinders companies from bringing in new technology such as computers or high-tech equipment, increases the error rate for input and production processes, increases productivity losses and reduces product or service quality.
The Conference Board study also addressed a number of myths surrounding illiteracy. It found, for example, that first generation immigration affects the illiteracy rate by only 2 percentage points. Indeed, the net impact of first and second generation immigration is positive. According to a demographic review published by Health and Welfare Canada, immigrants, both new and traditional groups, have a higher average level of education compared with those bom in Canada.
However, illiteracy strikes all ages but the older generation, in particular, is hit the hardest. A key finding of a Statistics Canada survey is that poor literacy is not limited to select groups of the unemployed and marginalized youth who have dropped out of school. Poor literacy is also found in a significant segment of the older employed adult work force.
For example, only 6 per cent of those between the ages of 16 and 24 have dysfunctional reading levels and only 7 per cent of those between the ages of 25 and 34 have this problem. But this percentage rises to 14 per cent of those between the ages of 35 and 54 and peaks at 36 per cent in the group aged 55 to 64.
It appears that literacy tends to deteriorate over time, partly because individuals do not continue to use their skills sufficiently. This finding has serious implications for an aging work force facing sharply increased training needs.
Those already in the work force will have to leam new jobs and/or new skills to keep up with the global economy. If a large segment have poor literacy skills, the situation will be grave.
Illiteracy is also expensive. The Canadian Business Task Force on Literacy estimates the cost of literacy to society as a whole at about $10 billion a year. It also estimates the cost of illiteracy to businesses at about $4 billion a year in lost productivity, accidents and direct training efforts.
Adult job training is key to increasing basic and technical literacy. There is a vast amount of untapped potential in the Canadian labour force but Canada lags far behind many other countries in adult training. The average Canadian worker participated in 6.7 hours of formal training in 1988. By contrast, an Australian worker received 17 hours; a Swede receive 170 hours and a Japanese 200 hours. Only one-third of Canadian companies provide any training to their employees at all.
In a Conference Board survey, 75 per cent of companies reported problems with basic employee literacy, but only 24 per cent had policies or training programs to deal with the issue.
Currently Canada spends about $5 billion on adult training, roughly one-eighth of the amount invested in formal education. And we are facing other countries that are increasing their investment in work force training. Germany, for example, has increased its expenditure by 45 per cent in the past three years. In Japan, companies are still increasing the time devoted to training. This large shortfall in adult training is clearly unacceptable in competitive terms.
March 24, 1992

One other major problem is the dropout rate. Nationally 30 per cent of Canadian students drop out of school, in some parts of Canada that number rises to 70 percent or more. According to the literacy survey, high school completion is key to every day reading skills. For example, 60 per cent of Canadians with only elementary schooling, or without any schooling at all, have very limited reading skills and have difficulty with written materials.
I would like to make a comparison between Canada and some other countries around the world when it comes to our standing on social programs. We will look at the output of that spending.
For example, in the United States they spend 5.3 per cent of their GNP on education; in Canada we spend 7.3 per cent of the GNP on education; West Germany spends 4.4 per cent, and Japan 5 per cent. So Canada spends more than any one of those four countries on education.
The United States spends 4.6 per cent of the GNP; West Germany spends 6.3 per cent; Japan spends 5 per cent; and Canada spends 6.6 per cent on health care.
While we spent more than any one of those four countries on social programs, the results are not very encouraging when we look at the dropout rate.
In Canada, for instance, only 72 per cent of youth aged 17 years are still in school; while in the United States 87 per cent are still in school; in West Germany 89 per cent; and Japan 94 per cent are still in school.
This information was compiled by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development.
So, Mr. Speaker, after bringing those statistics to your attention, one would suggest that there is room for improvement.
The motion before the House today calls on the government to establish a task force to discuss national education standards. This would involve consultation with the provincial governments and other sectors of Canadian society. Some of these could include incentives to motivate students to complete their education; improve standards in the core subjects of math, grammar and the sciences; strategies for the training and retention of teachers; methods of assessing students across Canada; regular professional development programs for educators; closer links between employers and the education
Private Members' Business
system; and support for disadvantaged young Canadians. I am sure there are many others that we could add.
Learning has become the key to economic success in the new global trade environment. This has made literacy a major economic issue; it is increasingly viewed as essential to economic performance. In order to be competitive, nations need a work force with a high degree of average functional literacy. But no society can have high quality output without high quality inputs.
I would like to close by saying that the only way to get a high standard of quality is to set national quality standards. The problem has already been well documented. Now it is time for the government to take action to implement long-term educational strategies that can help us tap the full potential of our most valuable resources, our intelligent and competent population.
This House could give leadership to the government by agreeing to this motion today.

speakeroldname: Mr. Vincent Della Noce (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State and to Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship; Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State of Canada
subtopic: EDUCATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to speak to the House today and address the motion of the hon. member for Ottawa Centre to establish a national task force to discuss national standards of education.
It is generally agreed that education has an impact on a country's prosperity, an impact that is felt at all levels of our society and by all its members.
It has become a cliche to say that we live in a constantly changing world. What is unusual in our history is the rapid rate of change we have seen during the past two or three decades.
Before, we could afford to believe that that we would always be able to adjust fairly easily to any changes that would occur.
In Canada, it was felt that our considerable reserve of natural resources would guarantee us an enviable and prosperous standard of living. Today, we see that is not the case. We must now realize that our standard of living will depend less on what we have in the way of natural resources or on our ability to process those resources, and increasingly on knowledge.

March 24, 1992
Private Members' Business
Canada, one of the foremost exporters of energy and primary resources, has gradually had to surrender economic power to industrialized countries that have left us far behind in areas like innovation, design, manufacturing and marketing. The increasing globalization of markets has changed the rules of competitiveness. With the creation of large economic and political blocs, whether we are talking about the European Community, the prosperous countries of South East Asia or the new Commonwealth of Independent States of the former Soviet Union, Canada is now facing competition that will become even more fierce in the years to come.
During the past decades, science and technology have become so important to the progress of a country that they must now be considered essential to of our economy, and indeed its prime assets.
Compared with companies in many industrialized countries, Canadian companies invest very little in research and development and rely less on advanced technology. No one will deny that our future prosperity will depend largely on education and training.
This is not the first time the government has considered these issues. In 1986, it made certain commitments that over the years would bring about considerable progress in this field. In 1987, the federal government and the provinces took part in a national seminar on post-secondary education which identified the basic premises for decisions that colleges and universities in Canada will face at the turn of the 21st century.
In 1988, this government introduced a scholarship program for outstanding graduate students in natural sciences, engineering and related disciplines. In the following year, the minister of science established the Network of Centres of Excellence Program, involving universities and hundreds of researchers across this country.
Aware of the important impact of a healthy environment on the quality of life, the environment minister announced in 1991 that $51 million would be spent over a period of six years to help Canadian universities put together a program for funding research and training in environmental studies. And that, Mr. Speaker, is only a fraction of our government's contribution to education.
Whether it is through the Department of the Environment, the Secretary of State, which is very interested in the teaching of official languages, or Statistics Canada, which collects many statistics on education, the federal government has overlooked nothing in making its contribution.
Nevertheless, it recognizes above all that education is an exclusive provincial jurisdiction and it has even suggested that they be responsible for labour force training from now on. That is why we are working with all the provinces and territories, both informally and in specific activities.
Year in and year out, the Government of Canada invests nearly $11 billion in training and education. We definitely consider it an investment because the real dividends it will pay in the form of better education will have a major impact on the standard of living of all Canadians.
We have a considerable interest in education and we believe that this interest must be matched with concrete action and effective measures. With this in mind, last year we launched a dialogue with Canadians, the Prosperity Initiative, on the best ways to meet the challenge of competitiveness.
We know how closely inter-related education, job creation, competitiveness and prosperity are. The Prosperity Initiative deals with these issues in national consultations held by a steering committee representing governments, business, labour, the scientific community, teachers and individuals.
The working papers resulting from these consultations recognize that our technical and scientific achievements are behind those of our competitors, that we do not give knowledge the importance it deserves and that companies do not invest enough in labour force training. This initiative seeks to set priorities for action, especially in the following areas: the implementation of a national strategy of excellence in the field of knowledge in order to acquire the skills necessary to face international competition; giving knowledge the importance it deserves among Canadians; better preparation of young people to enter the labour market; search for ways to encourage young people to take mathematics and science so as to better face international competition in a world that is continually being changed by technology.


March 24, 1992

We firmly believe that the success of such an undertaking depends in large measure on partnership. Let us have no illusions that the government alone can see the Prosperity Initiative through.
The working paper called Learning Well-Living Well clearly states: "This strategy must recognize the different strengths, needs and concerns of all stakeholders- investors and managers, workers and unions, educators, governments at all levels, and individual Canadians. It must also be a strategy that recognizes that actions are necessary at many levels in our society-at the level of the firm, the industry sector, the region and the country as a whole".
We have thus laid the foundation for joint action that will be the key to our future prosperity and well-being. Along with this initiative, we think that it is up to the federal government to encourage excellence and provincial initiatives to increase Canadians' skills and knowledge.
That is why national education standards seem desirable. That is also why we must praise the proposal of the hon. member for Ottawa Centre. These standards could be used to set criteria for improving the quality of education in all regions of the country. They could help us better meet the requirements of the labour market and they could be adapted to international standards and encourage the recognition of diplomas throughout the world and thus give rise to the beneficial exchange of skills between countries. In this spirit, the Prime Minister said three years ago that he would like to see national education standards rivaling those of our keenest competitors.
At the same time, he recognized that provincial jurisdiction in this area must be respected.

A task force on national education would be an excuse for failure to act precisely at a time when we must act quickly, at a time when federal and provincial governments are working closely together.
