Mr. Speaker, I must say that I am really quite pleased to see that a connection between education and economic development has become almost a matter of conventional wisdom in this House.
However, the debate in which we are engaged right now must be a terrible disappointment to those who are watching and to those who share a true concern that action be undertaken to improve the situation in our nation with respect to skills and education.
It is not unusual to hear a parliamentary secretary utter irrelevant statements designed for no other purpose than to make the government's inaction look good. It is rather difficult however to deal with the situation in which the proponent of the motion has hardly indicated what the meaning of the motion is.
I would congratulate the member for Ottawa Centre for his rather detailed analysis of a number of facts with respect to competitiveness. It bolsters the case rather abundantly already made that if Canada is to compete effectively, if its productivity is to be enhanced, then what we really should be doing is increasing the opportunities for skills development and educational development among our workers. This is the reason just the other day I proposed a motion in this House that there be established a national council on education.
I am entirely puzzled by the interpretation the member has placed upon his own motion. I will read the motion:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should
establish a national task force to discuss national standards of
education.
I would suspect that 90 per cent of the people reading that motion would interpret it to mean that there should be a national task force to develop appropriate means of testing in some direct or indirect way the level of performance of students in this country.
It is a position which has some legitimacy. It is a position that has been supported by industry. It has been supported by school boards across this country. It has been advocated by the Minister of Employment and Immigration. Most important, it has been looked at rather closely by the ministers of education in the provinces.

Private Members' Business
The result has been the development of the school achievements-indicated program which is designed to evaluate the performance of Canadian students, at least to measure the performance of the schools in providing students with essential skills in mathematics and in communications, reading and writing, as I understand it. This was achieved through a great deal of debate and controversy but nevertheless it is in train.
We might address that issue but I want to return to what the member for Ottawa Centre said ever so briefly, that there should be a national task force to look at teacher performance, a number of functional issues in the schools, student performance, the level of science teaching, mathematical skills, and so on to the extent that I really quite lost sight of the focus.
I wish that he had spent more time on his specific proposal and less time on documenting further what is already self-evident.
As if to make matters worse, as I said at the outset, the government member stood up and said that the government did all of these things with respect to its prosperity initiative. Everybody in the country knows that the prosperity initiative has been a lot of sound and fury signifying and amounting to nothing. There is not a single bit of evidence that the government has in fact taken its prosperity initiative seriously insofar as it concerns education and training.
When we were talking about a national educational council, I pointed out that education must involve everything from day care to universities, as well as training both on and off the job. There needed to be an independent facility by which we could establish leadership in respect of the provinces and the various jurisdictions involved in education, the kind of policy leadership, methodology leadership, standards leadership and all of those things that have been looked at very thoroughly in other jurisdictions with respect to improving education and making it more in tune with economic goals for this country.
I regret that the hon. member has not addressed the issue as he propounded it more thoroughly. I had a glimmer that in fact what he was proposing was something akin to the national council on education which I proposed the other day. If that is so, then I strongly support this motion.
In all fairness members of this place, of which there are few in attendance, certainly do have the right to expect that a proposal brought before this House be brought with sufficient specificity that we would understand what the proposal is and not a somewhat redundant analysis of the sort that we have already heard.
I am sure the member does, however, share the view that what really is at issue most fundamentally has been the gross inaction on the part of this government, if not its irresponsibility with respect to everything that has to do with what we are talking about here with respect to creating an opportunity environment for Canadian citizens.
It has in fact cut contributions to post-secondary education. It has in fact made it more difficult for students to attend colleges and universities by virtue of higher tuition fees and by virtue of less accessibility to those institutions. It has cut by $200 million in the last two budgets the funds available for the Canadian Jobs Strategy.
Just the other day the minister had the nerve-no, I take that back; he had no nerve at all. He sneaked in here on Friday to announce a program for summer employment support for students. He did this on a day when it would not be noticed because, in fact, what the government had done was it contradicted its prosperity agenda once more by making it that much more difficult for young people to attend post-secondary education institutions. He has the nerve to come in here and talk about what this government has done to improve the situation with respect to training, skills development and education.
If the hon. member for Ottawa Centre shares that view and if the hon. member for Ottawa Centre wants to see this government do something, no matter what it is, to indicate a real commitment to improving opportunities for Canadians, then I agree with him. I am sure that we will both continue to fight to get something besides nonsense out of this government.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
subtopic: EDUCATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak to the motion.
Certainly the motion put forward by my hon. colleague across the way deserves serious consideration. Canadians are certainly very well aware that in today's competitive world, the higher their level of education, the better their chances will be of enjoying a comfortable living.
March 24, 1992

If the purpose of my hon. friend's motion is to encourage discussion on national standards of education, then I am pleased to inform him that the government is already attempting to do that. The consultations that now are taking place are part of the prosperity initiative that was talked of earlier and it was announced by the government in the Speech from the Throne on May 13.
To quote from that speech: "Canada's ability to prosper in a global economy will be determined by the level of Canadian educational achievement, by the sophistication of our management skills and by our attitudes to work and to change. In the dawning knowledge age, how well we live will depend on how well we learn".
To quote one other passage from the throne speech that also addresses the hon. member's motion: "The time has come to reach a national consensus on performance, goals, partnerships and the priorities for learning. As part of my government's new agenda for prosperity, a discussion paper on learning will be published to stimulate and focus discussion on education and training".
The government fulfilled that promise on October 29 of last year. That was the day the Minister of Employment and Immigration released a discussion paper entitled Learning Well, Living Well which is an essential part of our prosperity initiative as a government. The paper identifies the challenges to learning that Canadians faced during this decade. We all agree to that and I agree with my hon. friend across the way on that. It focuses on the importance of developing a learning culture both at home and in the workplace. It suggests various ways of setting up a system of lifelong learning so that Canadians can acquire the skills needed for their very important working life.
On that same date last October, hon. members will recall that the Minister responsible for Industry, Science and Technology and International Trade tabled a discussion paper entitled "Prosperity through Competitiveness". The minister's paper zeroes in on the four areas we believe will help us to compete more successfully as a country.
First, it is science and technology that includes research, development and technological innovation. The
Private Members' Business
second deals with improving investment in Canada's enterprises and being much more innovative.
The third component addresses the need for an integrated domestic market as a base for Canadian businesses to compete internationally and globally. The fourth area talks about the necessity to open and exploit new international markets.
These two papers are now the focus for consultation, as my hon. colleague knows. It is being managed by the private sector steering group. It is not being managed by the government or government members. The group's members reflect a broad section of Canadians. In September it is planning to produce a plan for action for governments, business, labour, educators, scientists and, of course, ordinary Canadians.
These measures have been undertaken because the future economic health of this great country depends on our ability to compete internationally. That ability will be determined by our level of skills and education. Therefore, the prosperity initiative is closely linked to international competitiveness and learning.
My hon. colleague knows that education falls under the jurisdiction of the provinces. That is true and the federal government fully accepts that. Nevertheless, we are all Canadians. If we are to function as a strong and viable nation, then we must work in partnership; a partnership of federal, provincial, territorial and municipal governments; a partnership of business, of labour, of educators, of parents and students; in sum, a partnership of all Canadians working to ensure the future prosperity of this magnificent land. In other words, we are all moving toward the same goal and I know my hon. colleague's motion means the same, to have a better chance of meeting it.
What we are talking about here are goals, something that we can set our sights on so we can survive and prosper in the 21st century. That is why the prosperity initiative has helped define this discussion by suggesting several Canada-wide goals of excellence; for instance, cutting illiteracy rates in half; ensuring that 90 per cent of Canadians obtain high school diplomas or the equivalent by the age of 25; doubling the number of post-secondary graduates in mathematics, the sciences and engineering, and the quadrupling of training provided by employers to their employees.

March 24, 1992
Private Members' Business
Already, consultations are taking place. For example, more than 150 town hall meetings have been held across our country in small and large communities. The national steering group is also consulting with the national associations and they are seeking expertise from individuals. Cabinet ministers are meeting with representatives of their client groups.
These discussions are being driven by the private sector, not by the government. My hon. friend will be familiar with another example of how consultations have resulted in a new partnership that is working toward national standards. I am referring to the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and I think he referred to that.
Hon. members will recall that the board is comprised of 22 leaders from business, labour, education and training institutions and social action groups. This independent body determines its own priorities and hires its own staff. The board is studying the issue of training and occupational standards. This is extremely important. It means the partnership is working. It sets the tone for a productive relationship between the public and private sectors.
This is not just at the national level. They are now consulting with their local constituency groups, the provinces and the territories to set up a network of 50 to 75 local boards across the country. That initial meeting in my area will take place on April 22, and my community is certainly looking forward to it.
As well, Employment and Immigration is working hand in hand with the private sector bodies to develop occupational standards.
I want to say to my hon. colleague we are certainly in agreement. I certainly agree with his concern and interest in education and educational standards and with his interest in giving Canada's people, from infants to adults, the opportunity to receive education or retraining. It is important in our country today to build upon a solid base of educational expertise and make sure more people have the opportunity for enhanced education and training. Then they will have the kind of incomes we want Canadians to receive and the country will be in the kind of competitive situation we want it to be in.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to be standing here in this House this evening to discuss and debate this particular motion which deals with the possible setting up of a national task force to discuss national standards in education.
My colleague from Ottawa Centre is to be commended not only for his address, which reminded us of a number of points that were particularly important to Canada and Canadians today, but also for having undertaken this initiative.
I think it is important, as I begin this particular discussion, to indicate that if we want to set up a task force we must involve some of the key stakeholders from a number of different communities to help us come to grips with this particular problem, so no decision has been made initially. The idea is to have a group of people come together to attempt to work out a solution, therefore national standards need not involve testing or the evaluation of teachers as was suggested. It really could be a statement of goals, objectives, skills for development, something to set one's sights on, as my colleague has just mentioned.
I also want to say in a positive way, I do not want to be partisan on this issue, that the government's intent was really quite noble and there are a number of initiatives out there. In fact, I have said before, perhaps in a moment of passion, the rhetoric was fine, but where was the action? It is not simply the action in terms of the various commissions and groups that have been set up, but where are the concrete results that will bring us to having national standards or goals or objectives or call it what you will?
The other thing I want to mention initially is that it is important for us to recognize that education, almost any way you would define it, is a provincial constitutional responsibility. We accept that, but I also want to say, as strongly as I can, that we are looking for co-operation, not imposition. Surely co-operation is possible and I will come to that later.
One of the questions we must ask is why? Some of my colleagues have answered why from their perspective. Let me tell you why from my particular perspective. There are no real transferable standards in this country if one looks at the whole.
March 24, 1992



Take, for instance, our universities. If as a university student I want to transfer to another university to take the same program, the credits I already have would not be recognized.
The same applies to community colleges. For instance, if I had a university degree and I wanted to go to a community college, or if I had a college degree and I wanted to go to university, I have no guarantee the courses I had already taken would be evaluated at the same level by another university or college. It is even worse when you leave the province. This kind of situation exists within each province, and of course it is worse when you go to another province.
In high school for instance, it is very difficult for a student to transfer from ninth grade in one province to ninth grade in another province. The same applies to grade schools.

You would almost think that the trades might be simpler. It is for a number of trades where they have the red seal stamp of approval, that is, where groups have got together and decided what it is that constitutes that particular trade and what one must have in order to practise that trade elsewhere in Canada. But that is not a large number if one looks at all of the trades.
Even in the professions this is a problem. You cannot go from one province to another in a number of professions without having to jump through a whole lot of additional hoops and hurdles.
We must ask the question: Is this really absolutely necessary? Is it functional? Is it something that helps us as a country? I suspect it does not. I have not even raised the question of apprenticeships. We have many that exist in certain provinces that do not exist in others. If you wanted to transfer from one particular program to another, it is extremely difficult and very, very complicated.
This is a labyrinth and that is being kind. We need to bring some sort of order into it. What we are really seeking, at least I am from my particular perspective, is to try to make it much more logical.
When we talk about productivity, competitiveness, globalization, we see other countries reaching out. They
Private Members' Business
have different languages, different systems of education, different traditions and cultures. While we have significant differences in our own nation, those differences are in many instances not as large as they are in other nations. Surely we should be able to do that.
Let us look at Europe. There is increasing co-operation. In some of the Asian countries we see the same thing, as well as in a number of other countries in the world. We want people to be able to practise law, dentistry, carpentry, be a mechanic, a teacher, a pharmacist or do any number of things and be able to go from one area to the other more easily, without having to go through a lot of extras that are particularly debilitating and discouraging for people who have studied.
One of the problems we have in Canada is a lack of co-operation on a number of fronts. I have just completed a report with the co-operation of colleagues. It was less than perfect. We knew that. But we now see the premiers coming in with their own solutions and I wonder what is going to happen to this country in the final analysis.
On the economic scene there is a meeting being held now, or very shortly, and there are people coming in from different parts of the country with their solutions. If we look at social issues such as the provision of quality health care, we get different solutions from different parts of the country. In education there are different solutions from different parts of the country. There is very little meshing, co-operation, understanding, trying to streamline, trying to agree that we can do something in a way that can be portable from one area to another.
The question we have to ask is who speaks for the whole of Canada on those issues, whether they are economic, social, constitutional or educational. I could name a number of other areas such as the environment. Who speaks for the country? Who speaks for Canadians and puts Canadians first?
We are discussing tonight an issue which attempts to ensure that Canadians wherever they study, at whatever level, can take that learning, whether it is knowledge or skills, use it in another setting and be rewarded appropriately for it and be given the credit they deserve. That is what we are talking about. That is what it is all about. I could speak for a long, long time, but I shant. I would simply like to come to the end of my remarks by saying:

March 24, 1992
Private Members' Business

We find examples of co-operation throughout the world. In fact, countries whose economy is particularly stable and strong are countries where people have learned to work together, to co-operate. That is what I want for Canada. I do not want to impose a federal vision, but I want Canadians to get together and try and find flexible solutions that respond to the needs of all Canadians.

You will have noticed, Mr. Speaker, that this is a simple, straightforward motion. I think all my colleagues from each of the parties have been in general agreement with its direction and thrust. Therefore I ask through you, Mr. Speaker, for unanimous consent of the House for acceptance of this motion.
There is no vote. It is not binding. It seems to me that if we are sincere in what we have said, we ought to give this motion unanimous consent.

I therefore seek that unanimous consent, Mr. Speaker. [English]
